dialogues.speaker: INT. ROOM OLD BREWERY DAY
dialogues.text: Half in shadow, a man named VALLON, dressed in black, fas white clerical collar around his thick neck. He raises a his face, RAKES it across his right cheek, drawing BLOOD. flinch. The sharp SCRAPING of the jagged blade against skin is th hear. VALLON cuts himself similarly on the left cheek, then han ceremoniously to a BOY standing beside him. The boy, no m years old, looks at VALLON worshipfully, keen eyes shinin excitement. He starts to wipe the razor blade on the bott

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: No. Never. The blood stays on the blade, son. He hands the boy a dark red velvet pouch. Very carefully, as AMSTERDAM, wraps the razor up, hands it back to his fa From the shadows, VALLON now raises a long pole with a be crucifix mounted on the end, then holds his free hand out Amsterdam squeezes tight. VALLON nods toward the door. Amsterdam pulls it open. Out hallway. We hear SOUNDS that might be animal or human. MUSIC begins: a steady, driving cadence somewhere between hymn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALLON strides in long measured steps. Amsterdam has trou with him. They are walking down a long corridor that's like a tunne LIGHT stain the darkness. Sometimes Amsterdam glimpses a from the gloom. Once or twice he almost stumbles over a B across his path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another room, even smaller. The only decoration is a biza a Madonna and child painted on the wall. A beefy man picks up a home-made PIKE, its iron tip sharp point. He is smiling. The grin is huge, but cockeyed. It half of his face. The grotesque, unending grin is the res paralysis, and has given him a nickname: HAPPY JACK MULRA Jack lifts the pike carefully, then takes a candle from t down over a wooden cage full of rabbits. He slowly moves and forth across the cage top. Wax falls on the cage, spl unlucky rabbit. Jack thrusts the pike between the wooden bars, impaling t He pulls the pike from the cage and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack falls into step beside VALLON and Amsterdam. He hold the dead rabbit high, next to VALLON's cross.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: Did you bring the boy for a charm, Priest?

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: No, Jack. For a baptism. Now a WOMAN joins them. She's dressed in man's clothes, h by suspenders. She wears a set of IRON CLAWS. MUSIC builds, growing more insistent and more ominous. Now a figure looms before them. Over his street clothes, wears a rig of home-made armor made from fracgments of st chain and bits of leather. He carries a battle-axe as lig were a twig.

dialogues.speaker: RABBIT WARRIOR
dialogues.text: We'll send a few across the river today, Priest. He joins the procession. Another woman, as tough as the f again as large, and several more men, all armed with impl destruction, fall in beside him. Their faces are marked w Vallan's, or covered with ritual markings made with paint The group grows ever larger and more forbidding. occasion around them in the tunnel and scamper out of their way li frightened in a burrow.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: What's the fight?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: The Dead Rabbits against the Native Americans, same as ev be settled today.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (points to rabbit on pike) What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: SHANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group now turns down the last corridor, as dim and lo In the distance, there's a faint glimmer of light and the (MONK EASTMAN). VALLON stops near the door.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: I don't know you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (lightly) I suppose there's to be a fight. VALLON catches the heavy Celtic inflection in the man's v

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: Derry?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Donnegal. Name's Monk Eastman.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: And you want to fight, Mr. Eastman?

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: lf there's money in it.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: Fight for the Natives. They have a proper war chest.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Well, I might at that. But I thought I'd ask you first, s not quite a Native American myself.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: Let's see your skills, and we'll talk of payment later.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Fine. But if you like what you see, pay me double. Monk turns to the door with the grace of a dancer and del SHATTERING kick, sending it flying off its hinges. Clear streams in, and we see Monk Eastman plain for the first t in stature and girth, wearing a small DERBY that intentio head look even bigger.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: (as the door splinters settle) Stand with us then.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET DAY, (WINTER)
dialogues.text: WINTER WIND blows across a scene as strange and bleak as VALLON, carrying his cross high, steps through the doorwa slowly follow VALLON out of the building, which is three maybe a block long. A dilapidated sign identifies it as t Brewery. It is the tallest structure in the midst of low, squalid ALLEYS as narrow as a snakels back, and DIRT STREETS fill and filthy snow. A few PIGS wander forlornly about, rooti WASH hangs stiff, in the middle of the square, from a pec erected to some forgotten war hero. The Brewery occupies one side of a SQUARE surrounded by s and a couple of collapsed wooden sidewalks. If this place anything at all, it's a horrible hybrid of London's Limeh pioneer town in the American West whose best days have lo never came at all. VALLON stands still, staring across the square past the m battalion of irregulars waits for his signal. Now... very, very slowly...from around both sides of the ANOTHER GANG, in size the same as VALLON's, men and women Visigoths with HOMEMADE WEAPONS: knives, pitchforks, buil bricks, boards with sharp nails protruding from the ends. this second group is dressed in a long DUSTER which reach Several MEN in front of the group sport dusters made of l

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: Bill Poole! on whose challenge are we assembled? A MAN in a leather duster (BILL THE BUTCHER) steps forwar lean and fierce. And then there are his eyes. They do not real. The other is a huge, bulging PEARL upon which has b instead of a pupil, a full-color portrait of the AMERICAN On the side of the square, arranged to get a good view of combat, is a group of STREET KIDS, girls and boys, none o They talk and laugh excitedly among themselves, picking t favorites among the gangs as if the warriors were players

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: On the challenge of the Native Americans, to settle for g holds sway.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: Bene.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: By the ancient laws of combat, we offer our bodies to the warriors who have gone before us. Valor is avid for glory our wounds.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: But this time can you bear to look on the glory when it c you see it clear with your single eye?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Whoever fights untouched in battle has skill, but the war wounded has been touched by God.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: It wasn't God who touched your eye.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: It was God gave me guidance. Will you be able to look on like a gladiator, and not look away? No honorable man tur his death.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: I don't expect a death blow from your hand, Butcher. Let'

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: There is another matter.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: Say it out and quick, before spring gets here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: No Native American Warrior will dishonor himself with the halt and maimed.

dialogues.speaker: VALLON
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: So we would like to know whether Squire Jack Mulraney of can smile out of both sides of his face. A pause of a single second. Then HAPPY JACK takes the dea tip of his pike and hurls it across the square. It lands BUTCHER's feet. In a flash, BILL THE BUTCHER opens his coat. Inside, on a carries a CLEAVER, a CARVING KNIFE and other instruments trade, all stained with blood and gristle. Now the MAN st him removes the broad BELT from around his coat. The bras sharpened to a point, the leather studded with glass. The gallery of Street Kids tenses for action: they are th VALLON reaches up to the CROSS, pulls off the top piece, underneath, a gleaming sword point. He folds the arms of like the blades of a jackknife.

He impales a Native American on his cross and turns to fight again. Amsterdam and Shang exchange a glance of frightened, worr Then a Native American rushes at them, shouting for blood together. Amsterdam dives down in front of the man, sendi Shang BLUDGEONS the fallen warrior, using his lead-filled blackjack as Amsterdam kicks him savagely; the Native col unconscicus at their feet. Before the boys can thank one they are separaten by the SURGING GANGS all around them. VALLON BATTLES three Natives who come at him at once. Monk Eastman grabs a Native in his arms like a groom hugg raises his knee and brings the man crashing down across i spine like a Thanksgiving wishbone. The gallery of Street Kids is awed by this display of pow star in the making. The Rabbit Warrior in the home-made armor grins at an int lowers his battle-axe. The Native rushes as the Rabbit Warrior swings and SEPARATES the man from his legs A NATIVE WOMAN lowers her head and charges her Dead Rabbi delivering a shattering BUTT to his stomach. The NATIVE with the deadly belt uses it to TEAR a piece o face. Amsterdam, beginning now to be overwhelmed by the hellish around in growing PANIC for his father. A co SCAVENGERS scoot about, looting bodies. Amsterdam stays in the center of the square unmoving, und solitary vigil over his father. A TITLE is superimposed across this scene:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HARBOR DAY WINTER, (MATTE)
dialogues.text: The same afternoon. As the sun goes down, we have our fir (MATTE) at the low pale outlines of the city. The harbor is crowded with the high masts of sailing ship the island tip is the steeple of the city's tallest struc Church. The buildings of Wall Street are masses of concre streets surrounding them paved with cobblestones. Just ab district are the sloping buildings and rutted avenue of t The Old Brewery stands tall and forbidding over Paradise Above the Five Points, in the distance, we can glimpse so buildings. One wide street--Broadway--seems to run from t the island clear up into the woods just a few miles north The only SOUNDS are the lapping of the harbor water again creaking of masts in the winter WIND.

His SIROCCO, and he watches himself with bewildered seriousne Abruptly, he reaches down and SMASHES through the ice wit SLOW MOTION, we watch the ice fragments drift apart in th each bearing away a REFLECTION of Johnnyls face, like pie

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Where's your family, sonny? Johnny sees a POLICEMAN scrutinizing him.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (lilting brogue) My mother's just there. He gestures toward a ship, where MEN are unloading cargo. are lowering a thin pine COFFIN to dockside.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: On the trip, her insides all broke up. She wasn't dead an others fighting for her bed.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: And your father? Where's he, then?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I never knew him.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: (taking Johnny's hand) We better see to you, then.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: The Policeman leads an awed Johnny through the TEEMING st Points.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Where all those streets come together right ahead is the But most speak of the Five Points and mean anywhere betwe and the Bowery. Although the night's cold, the streets are jammed. WHORES carnival Gypsies sell themselves to any man sober enough SOUNDS of laughter and combat filter out from garish SALO Little Naples, the Hell Hole, the Egyptian Hall. In the midst of all this highlife are BEGGARS and the SIC charity, scrounging garbage in the street. An INDIGENT ba for a meager scrap of faod. A richly dressed WOMAN, ridin carriage, hides her eyes by raising a HUGE BOUQUET OF FLO her face.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Streets hereabouts are lively of an evening. The city com But there's places to put up a boy on his own. Three WOMEN, exquisitely costed, burst from the door of t Under the harsh glare of a nearby gas lamp, their faces a striking. Johnny STARES; there is something not right abo

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And those? What are those?

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Well, those. Those are, as you might say, a sort of... We SEE one of the women's faces, suddenly harsh under gas thickly caked make-up is a smiling TRANSVESTITE.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: ... sort of whatnot.

dialogues.speaker: TRANSVESTITE
dialogues.text: Say, policeman. I'll buy your bonny friend. The Policeman fetches the Transvestite a strong WHACK wit The Transvestite screams and falls ... and Johnny RUNS.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Hey! But Johnny's off, already lost in the mad street life.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MORTUARY NIGHT
dialogues.text: A funeral chapel. Vallan's body lies in state. He is wearing his gang regal Dead Rabbits FILE PAST his coffin in solemn tribute. A WO and kisses the body. Happy Jack Mulraney holds Vallon's c has obviously inherited. As a disreputable looking Minist PRAYERS, Happy Jack whispers to a silent Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: We passed the plate amongst ourselves. Come up with enoug all this, and carry you a while, too. He stuffs some money in Amsterdam's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Where will my father rest?

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: Potters Field, with everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: My father won't be buried with everyone else. He'll lie s ground, facing east.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: What difference where he faces?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: He'll face east for the second coming of Christ.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: Fine, son. When Jesus gets to the Battery you show Him th The Minister finishes the service. MR. CORNELIUS, a funer resembles one of his own customers, ushers in a WOMAN (MA lovely 10 year old GIRL (JENNY EVERDEKNE) by the hand. Th obviously drunk, the girl frightened.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Will you have music, entlegen

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (MAGGIE)
dialogues.text: My daughter'11 do any song you like.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: Not tonight, Maggie, we got... Monk Eastman interrupts from the Background.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE
dialogues.text: No, Jen, the other. Jenny starts to sing a HYMN. To avoid looking at the corp eyes rove all around the chapel until she SEES Amsterdam. straight at him until the hymn is over. And he does not t her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MORTUARY HALLWAY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mr. Cornelius is about to escort Maggie and Jenny into an crowded with mourners when a smartly-dressed man (DANIEL gestures to him from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Tweed would like a word, Mr. Cornelius. (Cornelius hesitates) Tweed of Tammany. At the mention of the name, Cornelius shoos Maggie and Je mourning room and shuts the door behind them. Then he giv full attention.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: In your office. At your pleasure, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the door opens, we see a man gazing out the narrow win spectacle in the next building. He is in his late 20s, al fleshy but dressed with dash: WILLIAM TWEED... "BOSS" TWE bemused, almost schalarly interest in the goings-on next This mortuary is located next to a bordello, where the wi uncurtained and the energy and variety of the activities inside is astounding. Tweed finally TURNS as Killoran opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Mr. Cornelius. With a view like this I'm surprised the de peace.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can...

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Yes. A favor.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Happy to serve, Mr. Tweed.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Excellent. Lend me something.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Oh, I don't know what I could ...

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: I believe in form and appearance, you see. Just like your believe in law, and the power of example. Our city is a l wilderness, sir. I'm asking you to help chasten it.

dialogues.speaker: CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: A matter of civic duty, then.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: And civic pride. I want you to help me set an example. (smiles) I only need to borrow one of your clients.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MORTUARY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Two native Americans open the door where Vallon is laid o Butcher STRIDES into the room. There is immediate TENSION, like an electric charge, as o stand in the doorway and crowd the hall stand while Bill coffin. He places a BLACK ROSE in Vallon's folded hands.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Tomorrow your cortege will cross Paradise Square, into te by the Native Americans. You will be permitted undisputed ways. That is our tribute. After that, any Rabbits wishin Native Americans and willing to swear blood loyalty will others will be dispatched. He starts out of the silent room, but STOPS when he sees looking at him with easy interest. Bill the Butcher STARES him down, but Monk's gaze never wavers.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'll expect you first.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Me? Oh, I don't know. All that talk of blood loyalty make spill blood when the price is right. But blood for ceremo communion.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You saw us fight today. You know we can pay any price.

dialogues.speaker: MONK
dialogues.text: Not mine. Not now, and not any time after.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: We'll see. Independence is a slippery thing. But being a that's dead dangerous. Bill brushes past Monk and leaves, followed by the NATIVE Now the RABBITS file out, with Monk among them.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: Come on, boyo. I'll put you up tonight.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'll do for myself, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: You can't. (Amsterdam stares at him) There's no mistaking you're his son. Happy Jack leaves Amsterdam alone in the room. Now, by himself, sure of no one seeing, Amsterdam CRIES.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MORTUARY NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mr. Cornelius is seated in his office, enjoying a late su looking out his window at the bordello activity across th at the door disturbs him: Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What's the cost to bury my father proud and proper?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: For a plot, a headstone, hands to break the earth...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: MR. CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: What are your current means? Amsterdam turns out his pockets, which contain Bill the B knife as well as the cash Happy Jack pressed on him. Corn all.

dialogues.speaker: MR. CORNELIUS
dialogues.text: Of course you'll have to wait three days for a city permi may do for part.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No. Amsterdam takes the knife back from Cornelius.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: That's owed another.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/PARADISE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: A grey day. Amsterdam stops in front of a window. He STRU scarf, trying to keep himself warm. His eye strays for a sees he is outside Mr. Cornelius' Establishment. Then he else.... .... his FATHER, propped up in a coffin, on public displa large sign beside the body: "The Dead End of Lawlessness. Crime. Tammany Means Justice." A sizeable CROWD is goggling at the body. Amsterdam BULLS the people to the street. He looks in the gutter, then lo Someone is watching him: Johnny. He's carrying an armful

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Firewood? Amsterdam grabs the longest plank Johnny has.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's a penny the load.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Later. He turns with the plank in his hand and starts to RUN bac crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hey! Johnny manages to GRAB the other end of the plank. But Am strong he YANKS him right along. The Crowd YELLS as it pa Amsterdam, who CHARGES through using the plank like a bat Johnny on the far end, born along by stubbornness and mom ... toward Mr. Cornelius' window. Amsterdam SHATTERS the Crowd SCATTERS in a blizzard of GLASS. Amsterdam stumbles into the window and against the coffin over, spilling Vallon's BODY, knocking the boy over. Amst himself up as Johnny stands frozen.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Help me. He starts to pull his fatherls body from the window.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Come on! Help me, goddamn it! In a daze, Johnny steps forward and HELPS Amsterdam pulls the street. Now: the SOUND of WHISTLES and WHEELS and RUNNING HORSES of POLICE arrives on the scene. Behind them, the Crowd re insults. The police RUN toward the window. Mr. Cornelius dithers a the crowd. Amsterdam and Johnny exchange a look. Then Johnny RUNS fo stays with the body... ... as the cops close in, SWINGING clubs. Amsterdam's gra couple of times. The Crowd yells. A COP swings his arm ba Amsterdam a good wallop... ... and someone grabs his arm: Bill The Butcher.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Easy, crusher. What's this all about?

dialogues.speaker: CRUSHER
dialogues.text: Ask the boy.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I paid Cornelius for my father to rest in honor. He told on a permit, but he only wanted time to... BILL picks up the Tammany sign from the ground.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Make another Arrangement, looks like. For advertising. (to cop) Better go along. I'll see to all this.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: The boy...

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Take the little malefactor. The Cops YANK the wildly flailing Amsterdam to his feet a to their wagon. Bill The Butcher approaches Cornelius.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Give the boy what he paid for.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET/PARADISE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: Amsterdam is HURLED into the police wagon. The door is lo He pulls himselt to his feet, looks out the tiny barred w ... Dead Rabbits join up in a rough funeral procession. S Vallon's body back into the coffin and place it onto Mr. funeral wagon. Monk Eastman LEAPS up onto the wagon and c lid tight. There are PEDDLERS everywhere. One dispenses drinks from samovar. A SAILOR hawks ships in a bottle, repeatedly sho advertisement: "Encourage the work of a landswamped sailo ARTIST offers to draw portraits of passersby. Funeral music is furnished by STREET MUSICIANS: a drummer player, and a horn player, with a couple of BUSKERS perfo for good measure. Mr. Cornelius takes the wagon reins and guides the horses square. The gang FOLLOWS solemnly behind. And across the square, the police wagon carrying Amsterda OFF in the opposite direction. He keeps looking out the t The funeral procession leaves the square and activity ret normal. Peddlers' CRIES once again fill the air. The Busk a snappier tune. SNOW begins to fall.

dialogues.speaker: INT- TOMBS DAY
dialogues.text: A huge, awful prison building modeled on an Egyptian maus Amsterdam--trying to hide his growing fear--waits on line PRISONERS, all of them older than he. At the head of the line, prisoners are being processed by couple of COPS. Each prisoner is asked several cursory qu told to strip. Every one of the men is SCARRED in some wa AMSTERDAM nears the front of the line. The MAN just ahead undresses. His left buttock is missing, and his back is c scars. A PRISONER behind Amsterdam WHISPERS loud enough f hear...

dialogues.speaker: PRISONER
dialogues.text: Ain't his first Tombs trip. ANSTERDAM steps up to the desk. The JAILER hardly takes n

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: What do they call you? And this is the first time in the film we have heard his

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Amsterdam. The JAILER looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: Your full name.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Vallon. The JAILER writes this down with a scratchy pen.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: First name?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I told you.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: (skeptical, resigned) Address?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Got none.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: I'll put city. Now what's your age? (Amsterdam shrugs.) Maybe twelve. Got a family?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No more.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: Well, where was they from when you had one?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (beat) City.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: (writing) Disrobe. As Amsterdam obeys, the Jailer turns to the Cop in the le standing at his side.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: What's the charge, Asbury?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Theft. Assault. Creating a ... The Jailer finishes writing. Amsterdam stands naked.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER
dialogues.text: Through that door there. (lowers his voice) And don't stand too near no one else.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CREMORE NIGHT
dialogues.text: The largest, noisiest, gaudiest dive we have yet seen, fu with bawdy CUSTOMERS even at this late hour. Therels a lo and women stand three deep; lots of small tables; a dance stage on which four blowsy DANCING GIRLS are giving out w number titled "My Father's Teeth Were Plugged With Zinc." One end of the bar is entirely taken up by a huge woaden attached hose. BAR ATTENDANTS DUMP the unfinished content the open barrel top as a line of FAR GONE DRUNKS wait the hose. Maggie, Jenny's mother, is close to the front of th drunk, hanging on to a mush-faced HOODLUM. Two VISITORS watch. One has a pad and makes quick SKETCHE

dialogues.speaker: VISITOR ONE
dialogues.text: Ought to be served in a trough, properly. Will you try so

dialogues.speaker: ARTIST
dialogues.text: Probably. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: VISITOR ONE
dialogues.text: All-Sorts. It's made of all that's poured and not drunk, salvage that's spilt. Maggie GRABS the hose, staring at the Artist as she takes hand moves quickly an the page, SKETCHING her.

dialogues.speaker: VISITOR
dialogues.text: (to Maggie) Your health. She SPITS at him, insulted. The Artist steps forward, put All-Sorts from the hose into his glass, and toasts Maggie turns away.... ...as Johnny enters, dragging a large SACK across the cro a far door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CREMORE BACK ROOM NIGHT
dialogues.text: Johnny RUSHES toward a wooden pen in the center of the ro cries from the crowd of SPORTSMEN of "Hurry it up" and "M Johnny dodges a kick or two before he finally arrives at He UPENDS the sack over the pit and a dozen live RATS tum GAMEMASTER slips Johnny a couple of cents as he starts hi

dialogues.speaker: GAMEMASTER
dialogues.text: Alright, gents and ladies, your bets now on Towser agains count to beat is ten rodents in three minutes. The crowd starts to place bets. A sleepy Johnny settles d ringside to watch the show. At a signal from the Gamemaster, a TRAINER tosses TOWSER- mongrel--into the ring. The crowd cheers lustily, continu bets, as the dog goes after the rats.The rats, fighting f bite the dog, attaching themselves to his body. Towser re gnawing the rats, SNAPPING them in half and spitting them As the CROWD cheers, and Towser kills, and money changes curls up and goes to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TOMBS NIGHT
dialogues.text: A row of cells, noisy and cold. The GUARD shoves Amsterda

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 2
dialogues.text: You get to live private until they come from the orphan's account of your tender years. There is nothing in the cell but a board for a bed, and a which Amsterdam can see the late winter moonlight. He loo the sky, but can see none.

dialogues.speaker: INT- MAIN ROOM/OLD BREWERY
dialogues.text: Jenny Everdeane and a girl FRIEND, her own age, huddle to corner of this huge space. The Friend opens her hand to s glimpse of what she's clutching: a penny.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Let me see! I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: (closing her hand) No! It's a danger.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Oh come on! It's not. (Friend shakes her head) Then tell me where you got it.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: From some man. He took me in his carriage. He only wanted to me fast.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I didn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Would he do the same with me?

dialogues.speaker: FRIEND
dialogues.text: I won't tell you if he's around again. (clutches penny tight) He's my secret.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Better keep it more careful, then. The Friend GETS UP and starts across the Brewery floor, a But she looks around her, across the sleeping, passed-out desperate families and their squalling infants, to see if noticed. A man and two women cast a glance her way. She looks away keeps watching her... then FANS OUT and starts to FOLLOW The Friend looks over her shoulder again. SEES the Man. L direction, SEES: the woman. And then: the second woman. A The Friend starts to RUN. The Trio runs after her. And no attention. The Friend PLUNGES into one of the warren of T off the Brewery floor. CAMERA plunges through the darkness, after her. Her foots is the SOUND of stumbling, falling, an angry CURSE and a struck. The FRIEND picks herself up out of the darkness a CAMERA following down the dank halls. Suddenly the TRIO runs AHEAD of the camera. There is a SC staps. And others SOUNDS follow quickly now: the dull THU object against bone, REPEATED several times; and then, ve the most terrible sound of all: silence. Then Two Women emerge from the darkness of the tunnel, fi penny. The Man, several steps behind them, throws an obje floor: it's a STONE, and it is covered with blood. He com Two Women quickly and GRABS the penny from them with a ha DRIPS blood and gore. They CHASE after him across the cro floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA races along the ornate corridor, past PORTRAITS of and self-important GENTLEMEN... through a door and into..

dialogues.speaker: INT. TWEEDIS OFFICE/TAMMANY NIGHT
dialogues.text: ... Tweed's domain. Small in size, but there are dozens o CANARIES all around. Tweed looks up startled as the door birds set up a COMMOTION. CAMERA bears down on Tweed as a pair of HANDS grabs him a against the wall. Bill The Butcher GLARES at Tweed. Some NATIVES come into him.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You come into the Five Points and you stole from me.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You stole Vallon. He was my kill. My example, of my power and made him yours.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: You're a lunatic to come here like... In the background, same of the NATIVES have begun to play removing the CANARY CAGES from their places and tossing t room.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Thank you. Just listen good. The Native Americans holds t We have prevailed. What you do outside the Points is your Outside is your city. Inside the Points is mine. Anyone w different, or does different, or thinks different... (smiles) ... theylll draw my unwelcame attention. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I do understand, yes. BILL pushes him away and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: But you don't understand at all. Bill keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: There's a whole city to share and all you see is your own

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (turns now) You just stay out of my place.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Yes, alright. Gladly. It's all blackjack jobs and panel g for a fiver. Bill waits for Tweed to continue. But Tweed stoops and tr canary in a cage.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: It's good work.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: As far as it goes.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You wouldn't be talking to me otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: But we're talking about different things, Bill. You descr I see the possibilities. Look to the future. There is so The Butcher starts to look interested.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TWEED'S OFFICE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Later. The Natives have cleared out; only Tweed and the B The cages have been restored to their proper places and t straightened. Bill stands beside the door, while Tweed re

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: There's things demanding to be done that no police force an obedient one. There's contributions from every dive an Loyalties to be secured and debts to be collected. BOSS TWEED (Cont'd) And now you and your Natives have emerged as the foremost Five Points, I'm prepared to extend you an opportunity. Y Tammany...

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: We work for no one.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: ... beside Tammany... in the performance of these civic o for a satisfactory... I'm prepared even to say equitable. participation. It's not the sort of responsibility the fo might have recognized. But then, the founding fathers nev city New York has become.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe you Tammany boys should do your own lifting and car work. Might build you up.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: We'd like to. I do miss it. But it's wiser for men in the give an appearance of probity.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Then get cops to do it.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus, no. The appearance of law must be upheld, espec being broken.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Appearance means nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Perhaps not within the Points. But the smart man could go Bill looks at Tweed for a long moment. The he SHOVES hims wall, pulls away the chair on which Tweed has been restin sits down close to him.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: If you can talk plain, maybe we can do business.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NIGHT
dialogues.text: A small slum thoroughfare congested by a splendid FIRE-WA "Americus Co./Tammany Hall." Curious SPECTATORS and panic RESIDENTS crowd around to watch a ramshackle building goi As Johnny presses through the crowd to get a good look at in a white coat and fancy fire helmet, steps off the fire an ONLOOKER.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Anyone inside?

dialogues.speaker: ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: No, praise God, but all we own... TWEED places a bucket over the only fire plug in the vici on it.

dialogues.speaker: ONLOOKER
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Waiting on reinforcements. The SOUND of another bell, nearby. Down the street from t direction come TWO MORE FIRE-WAGONS. The crowd starts che not move from the plug.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: That's not them. It's only the Black Jokes. Seems your fi their festivities. The wagons pull up next to the fire plug. Each of them ha "Black Joke Fire Co." written large on the side, but the party costumes, not regular uniforms. Some are dressed as Redcoats, still others as Indians. The FLAMES continue to devour the building, but Tweed doe the plug. He is approached by the Black Jake chief, who i Indian chief.

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF
dialogues.text: May I point out that the building is burning to ashes?

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Certainly. And may I then remind you, Pocahontas, that th the province of the Americus company, and you will kindly distance. Impasse. The rival Fire Companies size each other up and other. The building continues to burn. Tweed remains rega atop the fire plug. As the two COMPANIES are about to close with each other, sounds. Tweed's "reinforcements" have arrived: the Native by Bill The Butcher. They PILE OFF the wagons before the the Black Joke Co. is outnumbered, and it FALLS BACK. As Tweed takes the bucket off the fire plug.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Alright, boys! To work! The MEN of the Americus Co. give a great SHOUT and start hose is hitched up to the plug, buckets are filled, a pri water spluttering everywhere. But there is not much blaze left to combat and the Men qu frustrated. Tweed realizes this immediately.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Next building over, boys! Mustn't let it spread! The men charge into a neighboring building, STOMPING down through windows and SWINGING AXES with gusto, all to save is in no danger at all. A local poll named DANIEL KILLORAN detaches himself from approaches Tweed, giving him a hearty SLAP on the back.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Another proud night for Tammany, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Just tell them... (lowers his voice) ... to take enough to share. And not to steal so in the o Indeed, the Men are leaving the building with lots of LOO question their right to do this are promptly KNOCKED DOWN Bill The Butcher as he rushes by.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Jesus! Boss says to tell you to fight the fire from the f the back. Bill grins and leaves to spread the word as an angry WOMA Tweed.

dialogues.speaker: TEARFUL WOMAN
dialogues.text: The Black Joke could have saved my house!

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Black Joke had no business here, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: TEARFUL WOMAN
dialogues.text: Their business was to save my house!

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Tammany's your business. When we're here to call upon the other. We understand loss, Madam, and take care of our ow As Tweed leads her off, away from the blaze and the thiev boy sitting an the curb, watching the fire ... and watchi admiration. It's Johnny. The FLAMES light up his EYES as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny's face, as she tries to sleep on a narrow, filthy m mother Maggie lies beside her, crowding her, THRASHING ab troubled, drunken sleep.

dialogues.speaker: INT- ROOM/HIGH BRIDGE ORPHANS ASYLUM 2
dialogues.text: Amsterdam, eyes wide, lying on a cot in the middle of a l with KIDS - This place is a step or two up from the Brewe step. He stares at the ceiling, eyes grave, untroubled by of loneliness and fear that come from some of the beds su we move CLOSE on his EYES we...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGH BRIDGE ORPHANS ASYLUM DUSK
dialogues.text: ... the same eyes. But OLDER. Smart and full of savagery. It is Amsterdam. He is now in his early 20s, fully grown trifle with. Moving with jungle stealth and strength he . ... BURSTS out the door within the massive frame of a gre which hangs the sign "High Bridge Orphan Asylum." He star TITLE comes up... 1852 Pursued by GUARDS, Amsterdam runs hell-for-lather for a l bridge. It's a beautiful, stern old Romanesque span acros River with rolling banks of leafy trees on the far side. twilight, we can see that it is late spring, the end of a

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HIGH BRIDGE DUSK, (MATTE)
dialogues.text: Amsterdam is on the bridge. But he does not slow up until ... two orphanage GUARDS suddenly TACKLE him. A THIRD GUA a billy club. Amsterdam moans and curses, as much from fr

dialogues.speaker: SECOND GUARD
dialogues.text: It's Blackwell's Island certain now, boyo. The SECOND GUARD pulls AMSTERDAM up by the hair.

dialogues.speaker: THIRD GUARD
dialogues.text: Are you hurting? Let's hear you! Amsterdam won't give him the satisfaction. The Guard hits goes down, biting his lip so he won't cry out. Instead, h

dialogues.speaker: SECOND GUARD
dialogues.text: There's nothing funny, boyo! You been beat and turned bac

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: But every time you bring me back... you got to come furth

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CORLEAPS' HOOK PIER NIGHT
dialogues.text: Through the THICK FOG comes a ghostly apparition: a tatte CROSSBONES, made of rags, fluttering from the mast of a l vessel. The bow of the small boat breaks the fog, and on board we called SHEENY MIKE KURTZ and a huge black kid named JIMMY the cars. Johnny Sirocco, grown wary and wiry, peers into lookout, while Shang Draper, at the tiller, looks anxious The HULL of a large boat suddenly laoms in front of them, away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Hard starboard, Shang! Hard starboard!

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (panic) I told you forget that sailor stuff! Which way's star... Too late. Their Ticket craft crashes into the side with e make a LOUD THUMP and to send Shang sprawling.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Why don't we just knock on their front door? Shang gestures for QUIET. They wait and listen. No sound the boat above them. The boys throw two ROPE LADDERS over larger ship and start climbing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SHIP NIGHT
dialogues.text: The boys board the ship and gather on deck. They look aro spooked by the silence and the fog.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Spread out and make for the cabin. Moving slowly, the boys FAN OUT and move toward the cabin of the deck. Johnny stays close to Shang, holding onto th support.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (whispering) Nothing. Looks picked clean. Johnny stops. His hand, on the railing, is BLOODY. On the the deck, Sheeny Mike discovers more traces of blood and

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Bill and the Natives must have got here first. Johnny freezes in terror.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: What ... A long SHADOW falls across his shoulder. Shang jumps. Standing before him, holding a musket and covered in bloo CAPTAIN. A BUTCHER'S CLEAVER is imbedded between his neck With his dying energy, the Captain takes AIM at a petrifi fires his musket. Jimmy Spoils JUMPS the Captain from behind, sending the m wide. But the SOUND of the musket is thunderaus, and echo harbor. The boys panic and head for the side.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: That'll bring the Harbor cops for sure.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (about the dead man) Wait! Take him. If he's still alive he's good for ransom!

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: Hels dead as Good Friday, can't you...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Then we'll take Bill the Butcher's cleaver and sell the b medical students. They'll go five dollars for it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Come on. We'll get something out of this. Shang and Johnny start DRAGGING the body. Pushing, pullin panicked, the others help. As they boost the body over th of a bell cuts through the fog.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: The Harbors! Shang shoves the body off the side and into the boat. It resounding THUD. The boys CLAMBER after it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BOAT/RIVER NIGHT
dialogues.text: PUSHING OFF with cars, tearing their rope ladders from th ship, stumbling over the captain's body, the boys slip of The Harbor Police are so close to them they can see a pol shining. The boys stay absolutely still. Suddenly, WE SEE BOAT, breaking through the fog, then DISAPPEARING again.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: We can't go back to Corlears Hook, they'll be watching...

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: We'll make for Blackwells.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: And which way's that through this fog? Johnny throws his hands up for quiet. From close by comes COP'S VOICES. They are near. Very near. The boys stay as can... ... and the VOICES recede again in the thick fog.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: Should have asked them directions as they drifted by, Sha

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: You'd have liked that, wouldn't you Coal Face? You're the miss in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: Let's quiet, or we'll all be found out! As the BOYS stay still, their boat DRIFTS against an outc and STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Alright. We lay up here till first light. Then we run bac river.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) River pirates! Spoils settles back and tries to sleep. Johnny watches Sh Shang is too agitated to notice Johnny's stare. He looks the sun.

dialogues.speaker: EXT- BLACKWELLS ISLAND DAWN
dialogues.text: Shang drowses in the boat, fighting fatigue, then succumb h's brought awake suddenly by a loud SPLASH. He looks in the noise, SEES ... ... the BODY of the slaughtered ship's captain floating a company. He starts to cry out but Amsterdam GRABS him, lo in the crook of his arm.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (to everyone) Push off! Or his pipe snaps! The other boys are too stunned to resist. They push the b island.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Head straight out, then turn for the current. He pushes Shang away from him. The two boys stare at each remembering...

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (breathing hard) Figured you for dead.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Close enough.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: This is my crew. And welcome to join, if you've the mettl pirates and quick thieves and street brawlers...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (casual disdain) You're lost.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Yeah? You've no business saying anything against us! Do y you cost us? You know how much that body's worth?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I doubt it's worth the water it's floating in.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Fifteen dollars! Fifteen dollars from them medical ghouis

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'll make it back for you whatever it is, once we're in t keep sailing, or we're all done for.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (beat; to crew) Go ahead then. (beat; to Amsterdam) He was in his prime. He'd have fetched thirty dollars eas

dialogues.speaker: INT. HIDEOUT DAY
dialogues.text: A ramshackle room near the docks. It is part meeting hall quarters for the gang, and part clearing house forstolen presides over a boisterous meeting.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: You're as flat as Broadway going north. We can't run the We're poaching the Natives and the Harbor cops are lookin

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: The cops can go to blazes. Who cares about them?

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: Youlre all sand when it comes to cops, Shang. But do you go against the Natives?

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: It ain't the time to go against the Natives. We've got to Then we go.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: If we go like we did in the river, all of us'll sink. Amsterdam is sitting off to the side, watching this ongoi contemptuous detachment. Johnny sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Does Shang have the sand to ever go against the Natives?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't know. He acts like it.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: If he only acts, held be better on the stage. (looks away) Like her. His tone of voice has changed. Jenny Everdeane passes bef ravishing. Amsterdam STARES, as if he's trying to see int Jenny pays him scant attention as she moves across the ro

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Jenny Everdeane. Shang turned her into the best bludget i Jenny gives Shang silk scarfs, wallets and several purses

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Shes his mort, is she, as well as his best provider?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. But Jenny says she's anyone's she chooses. Jenny's haul is impressive. Shang picks a BRIGHT RED SILK distinctive PAISLEY design from the pile of stolen goods. with a shrewd, appreciative eye.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: That's the prize of the month. Spice Islands silk. He puts the scart in his coat pocket with a FLOURISH, the about Jenny in a proprietary way.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: You'll learn our way if you're going to be one of us, Ams Jenny reacts slightly to the mention of the name: she loo RECOGNIZES Amsterdam now.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Every one of us gives a portion of all they steal to the than men, being morts.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Yeah? And why is that?

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Because morts have more resources. Men can work only on t mort can turn out on her back.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I mean, why give at all? Why don't they keep for themselv

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: If you think there's something off about my way of runnin no place in this gang.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I got no place anyway, and you got no gang. This ain't a what you say. It's a mob. There's a tense hush in the grubby room. Shang takes his Jenny, wanting to be restrained.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (smiling) It's all your play now, Shang. Maybe you can set him righ Jenny hands him a cane. Barely managing to hide his reluc starts--slowly--toward Amsterdam, who stands his ground. back to give them room in this tiny space. Shang pulls th it's a SWORD CANE, but Amsterdam shows no fear. He shifts little, watching ... and they're interrupted by a...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (HAPPY JACK)
dialogues.text: You boys settle with me before you settle each other. They turn to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: I've come for my due and proper, Shang. Happy Jack Mulraney (the Dead Rabbit gang member with the face) stands before them in a POLICEMAN'S UNIFORM-sparkli splendid--a leather helmet and long coat. In his hand, he NIGHTSTICK.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: As agreed, then, Jack. Refreshment? Shang OPENS the top of the gold-handled sword cane. Insid solid LUMPS of cocaine. Jack reaches for the choicest.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Still smiling, are you?

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: (sizing him up) It's the young Vallon, is it? I hardly recognized you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I hardly knew you under that hat, Jack. By now, Jack has taken not only the cocaine, and the mone offers, but several of the purses and wallets Jenny deliv stares at him with contempt, and he laughs, tossing one o at her.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: There. For your respect. Jack turns to leave but a BRASH BOY blocks his way. Movin Jack bashes the Boy to the floor with his nightstick.

dialogues.speaker: HAPPY JACK
dialogues.text: Anybody else? Any number at all, come on. Several of the gang make a move toward Jack, but Shang WA Jack departs UNHARMED, to general disgust. Jenny walks ba room to help the Brash Boy. Shang GLARES at Amsterdam, sl back into his cane and follows Jenny, trying to explain h

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Is that sand we've just seen?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's politics.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARADISE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: A hot summer day. All the TRADESMEN are out in force, jam and the side streets leading to it. Amsterdam walks fast crowd, enjoying the freedom and the bustle, as Johnny tag behind him.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I've got my own way to go, why don't you find yours?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Because your way's different, and I want to see where it (Amsterdam looks at him) Unless you say otherwise. Amsterdam shrugs and keep walki

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You act like you have something in mind, like you know ev you'll be doing the next. Me, I don't figure on tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Well, if you shut up a while maybe it'd come on its own. (he stops, looks) Now what the hell's that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (following his glance) Oh that's heaven. WE SEE what they're looking at: the Old Brewery. In worse before, but shut-down, abandoned. A tattered banner flaps front door: "Future Home of the Five Points Mission/ Prai Reverend Shadrach Raleigh, Pastor."

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: The city shut down the Brewery as unfit to live and Tamma to this minister.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAN
dialogues.text: What's Tammany?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Why Tammany ... you don't know? Tammany makes the city ru organization that's like... like the Native Americans, on the whole city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Johnny continues to speak, we see Tammany tactics in a WARD-HEALERS dispensing coal to the poor, and TOUGHS stea butcher's wagons; a political PARADE with fife and drum-a politicians--including Boss Tweed--in ceremonial Indian c group of GOONS busting up a saloon; Tweed making a speech CONSTITUENTS and a Tammany Fire Company tearing through t scattering everyone in their way, finally revealing they to a fire but are CRASING OFF a rival fire company.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: They seem like the law, but they got a way of acting outs Anything that happens in this city, on the straight or on Tammany's a part of, and Boss Tweedls the heart of Tamman

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARADISE SQUARE,/OLD BREWERY DAY
dialogues.text: Amsterdam studies Johnnyls enthusiastic face.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: They're the best gang there is.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: So if Tammany's the best, go with Tammany. What are you r mob for?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: 'Cause they're more my size for now. With Tammany, you go large, something that makes them take notice of you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAN
dialogues.text: You're better oft without their notice. You can run free, schemes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: But if your schemes have size, you need size to bring the

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What are you thinking? Johnny shrugs, grins: he doesn't want to give anything aw understands, turns toward the Brewery.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Let me in if you ever get it figured. Amsterdam starts toward the Old Brewery, Johnny keeping s

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'll go on my own from here. Johnny STOPS and Amsterdam continues on by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Echoing. Dank. Amsterdam holds a candle high for light. R crosses the main floor, enters one of the side tunnels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny room we recognize from the first scene: this is th Amsterdam lived with his father. He crouches and TEARS UP floorboards, then quickly LOWERS HIMSELF into the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short tunnel under the Brewery floor, the kind a kid mi Amsterdam has trouble crawling through it. DIRT and ROCK until he finds what he wants stuck in a shallow hole; a b MONEY PURSE; and a PAPER-WRAPPED PACKAGE. Amsterdam snaps open the purse to make sure the little bi still there, then turns his attention to the package. He Inside is the PIRATE KNIFE that Bill the Butcher used to father. Amsterdam handles the knife carefully as he opens it. The makes the blade GLEAMS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY/OLD BREWERY DAY
dialogues.text: A shock of summer SUNLIGHT as Amsterdam emerges from one entrances of the Brewery onto a fetid alley filled with r broken glass and insensible drunks. Amsterdam looks carefully up and down the alley, letting to the bright light. Ahead of him, he SEES ... Shang Draper, in jovial conversation with a SECOND MAN we recognize. The man is bareheaded, and has a deep scar run front clear down the center of his bald head. Amsterdam w Shang takes the RED SILK SCARF he got from Jenny's swag a the Second Man. He and Shang SHAKE HANDS, as if they have business deal, and the Second Man walks away. Amsterdam PRESSES himself close to the door as Shang LOOK doesn't see Amsterdam... and walks off in the opposite di Paradise Square.

dialogues.speaker: INT- RECEPTION ROOM AND TWEED'S OFFICE DAY
dialogues.text: The main room is as loud and as prosperous as the stock e Butcher makes his way past Small GROUPS of men engaged in dealings of dubious virtue. Bill knocks on the door to Tweed's private office while h Inside is Boss Tweed, seated in a large WOODEN BOX like a Around him are various PETITIONERS, and his assistant Dan

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: I dread city stimmers. They bring illness and beget vermi PETITIONER #l (GLEASON) My plague box fends off all pestilence. Its elixir combat

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: We can't have every citizen of the Five Points boxed up l

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: But the season is vicious, and I must take thought of our Mr. Gleason, I'd like you to shake hands with Mr. Barnett Gleason, dubious, shakes hands with PETITIONER #2 as Bill looks on with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: A friend and owner of an estimable carting service. Work arrangement whereby the citizenry can receive the benefit wondrous elixir outside this excellent box. At a cost, Mr much the barrel ...

dialogues.speaker: GLEASON
dialogues.text: (figuring rapidly) Oh, perhaps twenty-five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: ...and how much, Mr. Baff, for haulage and distribution..

dialogues.speaker: BAFF
dialogues.text: The same again. At least.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: At least. That's a price of fifty dollars. And greedy, lo (Gleason and Baff splutter) But a price that Tammany, in its generosity, will meet. M bill for a hundred. We'll each have half. And I'll retain further experiment. Hello, Bill. Killoran LEADS the astonished Gleason and Baff away as Bi

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Bolt the door. Bill complies. As Tweed speaks and the anti-plague VAPORS head, he keeps his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Scotchy Lavelle's gone wrong in his accounts.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I know. Scotchy's a good man.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Not good enough to rake thirty percent of our share from it for his own. (opens his eyes) You got to give him over, Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I can't do that. No matter what he steals, I still get mo any two others. As do you.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: Alright then. What about Charles McGloin? He's running a one side. Did you know that? (Bill shrugs) I can't get a day's work done for all the good citizens p complaining about crime and corruption all over the Point Tammany of carelesoness. Some even suspect ... a few prac (eying Bill significantly)  ... our complicity with this rampant criminality. We must Tammany stands behind the letter of the law. We need to s

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (beat) Charles McGloin will do.

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: I'll set the trial for Friday.

dialogues.speaker: EXT- TOMBS DAY
dialogues.text: CAMERA moves high along the outside wall, past small rect that pass for jail windows. EYES peer out, as if a peep s directly below in the Tombs courtyard. A PRISONER is bein gallows by having a hood tied to his head. The CROWD is in a carnival mood; HOT CORN GIRLS, STREET V "HOKEY-POKEY" (i.e., ice cream) MERCHANTS, even BUSKERS, holiday spirit. Jenny works through the crowd, pushing and smiling her wa raucous merrymakers. She stops once or twice to have a wo GENTLEMAN, flirts for a moment, then moves on. Further back in the crowd, Amsterdam NOTICES her. He watc through the crowd with an admiration that quickly turns t he realizes what she's doing: picking pockets. The best b Five Points. He starts to FOLLOW her. Jenny has worked her way close to the hanging platform, b intent on her job she has not noticed Amsterdam. The clos the closer the spectacle and richer the pickings: Jenny's absolute. On the platform, an ASSISTANT HANGMAN addresses

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT HANGMAN
dialogues.text: Those interested in the effects of the condemned please c

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Part of the Crowd PRESSES in toward the platform, tempora Amsterdam's view of Jenny. He is right against the platfo

dialogues.speaker: ASSISTANT HANGMAN
dialogues.text: What am I bid for this coat? A coat of some wear but exce containing a rather remarkable pocket silk...

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN CROWD
dialogues.text: Bid a quarter!

dialogues.speaker: HANGMAN
dialogues.text: A quarter, thank you. Do I hear fifty cents? Fifty cents? The Hangman is holding up the condemned man's coat which SILK SCARF Amsterdam saw Shang give away. Amsterdam flips quarter, reaches out and GRABS the handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Here. Just for the silk. He stuffs it into his pocket and starts to PUSH his way t On the platform, the WARDEN steps forward holding a primi

dialogues.speaker: WARDEN
dialogues.text: Do you have any last remarks, Charles McGloin? McGloin grunts from underneath the hood.

dialogues.speaker: MCGLOIN
dialogues.text: Not from under this hood I don't. Crowd near the platform begins to CHANT "No hood, no hood Warden puts his hand on the hood, starts to remove it... ... and the Crowd CHEERS. Amsterdam turns, SEES: Charles with a deep scar running front to back on his head. The v saw in the alley with Shang. McGloin acknowledges the cheers of the crowd. The Warden megaphone close and McGloin bellows...

dialogues.speaker: MCGLOIN
dialogues.text: I never struck a foul blow or turned a card and may God g friend! The Crowd ROAR approval at these words. Amsterdam PUSHES crowd, looking for Jenny ... SPOTTING her finally... ... while up on the platform, the NOOSE is placed around and he is HOISTED UP in no time. We hear his neck SNAP. H after death. The Crowd raises a zighty cheer.

dialogues.speaker: EXT./INT. BROADWAY AND BROADWAY STAGE DAY
dialogues.text: Amsterdam walks with a crowd toward a waiting Broadway st that looks like a horsedrawn train car. The stage will ta back uptown from the hanging. He is working his way toward Jenny, who is now BOARDING t Amsterdam DASHES through the crowd and SQUEEZES onto the moves forward with a JOLT. Once on board, Amsterdam looks through the jammed car, SE to sit down - A MAN has offered her his seat. She smiles sits... ... and arranges her hands genteelly on her lap. The Man and she smiles up at him again. He is bequiled. Amsterdam manages to get a little closer.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I hope you won't think me rude if I speak.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: No, sir. You look a proper Gentleman down to the ground. As this conversation continues, we watch-not only Jenny a conversation, and Amsterdam watching them; but we begin t Amsterdam SEES. Although Jenny's hands apparently remain lap, her RIGHT HAND moves SLOWLY out from her wrap... tow

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't want you to think me forward, you see. ... and BRUSHES past his jacket. He does not notice or fe Jenny's hand GLIDES past his THIGH ... nearly brushing it across his pelvis and around his buttocks...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Does it matter to you what I think?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well, I might like it to.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Oh. ...toward his pocket. The Man is in Jenny's thrall. He fe continues to have no idea what is going on. But Amsterdam silken, surreptitious move of her HAND across The Man's b CARESS that Amsterdam can feel. Jenny's grace is balletic she picks The Man's pocket, she is, without knowing it, a Amsterdam

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I mean, if you would like.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I might like, sir. But I can't say now. Her hand HOVERS above his pocket, waiting for the SWAY of match and mask her movement....

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Why? ... and she starts to get up as soon as the stage JOSTLES full of passengers LEANS into one another... ... and Jenny's hand SLIDES the Man's WALLET from his tro he recovers his balance. Amsterdam watches her withdraw h flash and hide it beneath her wrap.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Because this is my stop.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: May I walk with you a little, then?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (firmly) That would be too bold.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: But I'll never see you again.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I come every Thursday to the Tombs to see my father.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I'll look for you. Jenny fetches him another fine SMILE--it's almost demure- way off the rear entrance of the stage. lt PULLS AWAY up Broadway and Jenny walks briskly toward

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ALLEY/BROADWAY DAY
dialogues.text: Jenny looks to make sure she has the alley to herself, th a little... ... and her arms seem to come off. She has been wearing a ARTIFICIAL ARMS, hollow inside, which she can leave folde misleadingly while she goes about her pickpocketing. She's folding up the appliance--cotton sewn over a soft f behind her makes her turn.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: May I walk with you a little, then?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BROADWAY DAY
dialogues.text: As Jenny and Amsterdam walk through the noisy bustle of t thoroughfare.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Are you a spy, then?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Got no one to spy for. I'm an appreciator, you might say.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Appreciator of what?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: A good touch. She STOPS in the street, looks him straight in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Don't bother with the chat. If you want me, we come to a arrangement. lf the terms is right, then I decide how you do it or not.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Just take a minute, I was Just...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I know what you was just. I had years already of what you know how I got so good at thieving? So's I wouldn't have everyone who had the ned. Now I do it when I want to for to. Otherwise I don't do it, and don't have to do it, and anyone's rules but my own.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What about Shang's rules? You pay a lot over to him. The the better his. It don't seem gute right.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (a little curious now) What's it to you?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Give him this. He hands her the RED SILK SCARF. She recognizes it instan one she gave Shang.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: And you can keep a little more of what you earned.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: How'd you come by this?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I got my own touch.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Are you making me a present, or making an Arrangement?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It's your rules, right? So you decide. She looks at him for a moment, then starts to TIE the sca neck like a kerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gentlemen's WALLET skims across a pitted wooden table, Shang's hand. Jenny is giving him her CUT. He opens the w at Jenny. No more goods are forthcoming. Amsterdam, hangi them both. Shang SEES the RED SILK SCARF, tied around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Pretty slim cut for a hanging day. Where'd you get that?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: From Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (beat) It don't suit you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET AND PARADISE SQUARE NIGHT
dialogues.text: A SWELTERING evening. The streets are jammed with REVELER Some people sleep in doorways in futile search for fresh Mulraney leads a group of apprehensive UPTOWN CITIZENS pa whores.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Commissioner Brunt said to spare you nothing concerning c

dialogues.speaker: CITIZEN
dialogues.text: Nothing but our safety, of course.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: All's snug around Paradise Square in my company, squire. He gestures toward the street, down which one oi Mr. Barn is being drawn by a team of WHEEZING NAGS. The cart bears massive barrels of what a colorful banner anti-pestilence influenza-thwarting solution... a service Hall." As the wagon draws abreast of a large group of lan RESIDENTS, HOSES spurt waves of solution all over the str are SOAKED. Jack and his Citizens jump back just in time.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Tammany makes the streets nanitary, I make 'am safe.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN CITIZEN
dialogues.text: (apprehensive) Even against them? A small distance behind the anti-plague cart, moving in r come some of Shang's mob, heading aimlessly across the Sq action

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Against them especially. Let me demonstrate. Jack takes out his GOLD WATCH AND CHAIN, which he HANGS c nearby lamppost. Then, very casually, he leads the Citize

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: We'll be back for this at our leisure.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN CITIZEN
dialogues.text: You dare leave it here?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Safe as a vault, lady. Since all knows it's mine. The Gang draws abreast of the lamppost. No one makes a mo watch until one of the YOUNGEST BOYS reaches out ... but Shang knocks his hand away. Jack, at a distance, NODS app

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: You know that's Jack's.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It should be hangin' off Jack's vest, then. Not here, lik

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: That watch is a small price for free run of the Points.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: If it's free, how come we pay so much? Wo shouldn't pay f

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: We don't tight when we don't have to. It's not warring th the living day to day.

dialogues.speaker: ANSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (smiles) Is that right? Did I hear that correct? John, did we hear Eyes now on Johnny. Jenny looks at him with great interes

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (uneasy pause) We heard the same.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: So then. He reaches for the watch.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET AND PARADISE SQUARE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Happy Jack stands at the lamppost, aghast. A WOMAN lowers retches. Jackls watch and chain are still in place. But the watch has been SMASHED. And hanging from the chai skinned and strangled.

dialogues.speaker: INT- HIDEOUT
dialogues.text: Happy Jack stands with his Citizens. The room QUIETS as, mob notices him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You! He GRABS the Young Boy who had reached for his watch on t starts to BEAT him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What'd you do to my watch, you dirty little bastard... Jack breaks the Boy's hand with his nightstick. The Boy S and FAINTS. So does one of the Women in the group. Jack t other hand.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hands won't be so quick in future.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: That's enough sport this evening, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (stepping forward) It wasn't him. All turn to look at Johnny. Jack drops the Boy's hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I have word for you from who did it. You're to meet him a Chinese Pagoda.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPAPROW'S CHINESE PAGODA NIGHT
dialogues.text: A low and lunatic place: a combination of an opium dream Arabian Nights and a panel from a Bosch triptych. FAN-TAN Orientals; WOMEN and CHILDREN of various colors suspended the ceiling as MEN and WOMEN in a secondfloor GALLERY poi JOKE. On the main floor, a long line waits for a shot at All-Sorts. Jack charges in the front door, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: All right, step out, you yellow... All the NOISE subsides. Only the Fan-Tan game continues; nothing is so interesting that these Orientals will stop Now Amsterdam STEPS right in front of him. It's a grandst

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Hello, Happy Jack. I'm the one you're looking for.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Then you're marked for dead. Jack lunges ahead, swinging his NIGHT STICK. Amsterdam th across his path. Jack stumbles, goes down, dropping his n Amsterdam grabs it, jumps on top of him, HITS him twice o head. There is a CRACKING SOUND. The PATRONS of the Pagod

dialogues.speaker: INT. SPARROW'S CHINESE PAGODA NIGHT
dialogues.text: Later. Festive again. And no sign of Amsterdam. Two PATRONS step away from the all-sorts barrel. Hanging like the cat from the watch chain is the BODY of Happy Ja belt has been removed from his trousers, tied like a NOOS throat, then looped over the spigot. His TEETH lie scatte around him. His NIGHT STICK has been jammed down his thro

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOCKS/HIDEOUT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Amsterdam holds the FANCY COAT from Jack's uniform over h Carefully, he DRAPES the coat over Jenny's shoulders. SHA

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: I gave no order for this. Amsterdam says nothing at first, just holds his hand out: RED SILK SCKRF.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (very quietly)  Never mind giving orders. What were you giving this for?

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: I'm calling you out, Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I got this at the hanging. It was Charles McGloin's. Ever you take it from Jenny. What was MCGloin doing with it? W to him for?

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: I didn't give it to him. Why would I give it to him?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I gaw you give it to him. Last week, behind the Old Brewe

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (to group) He's gone flat. I got no reason to trade with the Native

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What about stepping up in the world, as it were, and leav us behind. There's a reason. Making a separate arrangemen with the one Native so stupid and luckless that he got hu the ground, Shang.

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: (very edgy now; to group) Who believes what he's saying? Can any of you believe wha

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Bene. We'll see. Any of you that believes I did proper by Mulraney tonight, stand beside me. Any of you that still with the cops, and Shang's way with the Natives, go to hi (to Shang) Or should we settle right now, you and me, and just see w left standing?

dialogues.speaker: SHANG
dialogues.text: Let see where they stand. Jenny rises, stands next to Amsterdam. Jimmy Spoils, John are next. Now the other members of the mob move in cluste with Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What's your pleasure, Shang? One of the YOUNG BOYS has a dead rat blackjack hanging fr Shang grabs it. He BITES the head oft the rat and spits i Amsterdam. Amsterdam almost smiles at him. Shang sneers, the rat, and LEAVES.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: This mob ever have a proper name?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: We was called after Shang when we was named at all.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: We're the Dead Rabbits from now. They were the best. They They were legend, and we'll live up to them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOCKS/WATERFRONT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Amsterdam sits on an empty pier, watching the ships in th a SUDDEN RUSTLING NOISE as a NOOSE coils around his neck. It's Jenny. She's slipped the SILK Amsterdam gave her clo and she's TIGHTENING it. Amsterdam starts to resist. Then she's looking at him. She uses the silk to bring his face closer to hers. She K

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What's this then?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Payment for the silk. Then DROPS the silk from his throat and starts to touch h hands are under her skirt. Then, under the cloudy moonlig make love.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOCKS/WATERFRONT NIGHT
dialogues.text: Later. Amsterdam pulls Happy Jack's uniform COAT over Jen warm in the chill air.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You were waiting for me out here, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Maybe I was, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You was that sure of me?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Sure enough to wait, anyway. Waiting don't cost nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It don't do to be sure. I could go away just as easy.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Alright. He sweeps the coat away from her body, allowing her to le

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I'll say when I want to, not you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Stay then. (beat; smile) One way or another, I get what I want.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (looking at him) Yeah. If it was just a shag you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You're a gypsy, are you, come to tell my fortune? Go ahea what I'm wanting.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You got blood in your eye for someone.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It's just I can't look away, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Who from?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Bill Poole.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You better get someone else in your sights. No one's ever

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: 'Cause he's mine, that's why. I'll take his one eye, and him, piece by small piece.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You have a plan for this? You going to raise a militia? I the Butcher don't even know about you or care if he does.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: He'll know about me soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: And after the Butcher?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You'll be in love with me.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Love you? You just had me. You can have a mort any time y look for more than that.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: That's taking love, not giving it. I want it to be just y else for either.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Why?
