dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: 'Cause none of us means nothing in life except one to the

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I don't know I want to mean something, to you or anybody. good in that? He stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: We'll see. Jenny pulls the coat tighter around her.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It'll take a while if we do. If we ever do.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: And what about the meantime?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Meantime's business.

dialogues.speaker: EXT PARADISE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: A CROWD gathers in one of the main thoroughfares bisectin beefy SPEAKER is making an anti-Irish speech on behalf of a mayoral candidate supported by Tammany's current rivals Know-Nothing Party. Hand-painted signs are everywhere, be unsavory likeness. A couple of BUSKERS provide a musical political spiel.

dialogues.speaker: SPEAKER
dialogues.text: The potato is a thick vegetable. Heavy. Meaty. Comes out dirty and stays that way unless you scrub it and boil it (cheers and laughs from crowd) We don't want to keep lem out of the country! We'll even at our table! But we ain't gonna vote 'em into office. Much CHEERING and jovial approval from the Crowd. On its Amsterdam and the Dead Rabbits make their way roughly acr

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: Any Irish hears that will be out for blood.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: The Irish is too busy building up Tammany. That's where t muscle goes. Once they're inside with their cronies, they own outside. Tammany'd steal the air and rent the dayligh

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: We'd do the same. AMSTERDkM Not against our own we wouldn't. That's the difference.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Tammany earns better. That's the difference.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I ain't seen their ned yet. Johnny stops walking, betraying slight annoyance that he the day's deal.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You will at day's end, that's our arrangement. A quarter they're repeaters or not. I'm telling you, we got a squar

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: It's sound, Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, it's ned anyway. Just make sure you count it

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's just a day's job, we don't have to make it a life's Tammany today and kill them tomorrow, if that's our pleas

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: So we're politicians just for today.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Not for a minute. We're better than that. We're thieves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dead Rabbits go about the business of rounding up Tam pick up DRUNKS in alleys; Jenny and some of the Dead Rabb PATRONS in a whore house; Rabbits shanghai SAILORS from s CITIZENS as they walk along the street, either wheedling get them to vote. It's the strong arm of democracy.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. POLLING PLACE DAY
dialogues.text: On one side of the door, some Dead Rabbits, with a RABBLE voters; on the other, POLICE doing their best. Behind and various WARD HEELERS and SMALL-TIME POLITICIANS, represen Know-Nothing candidate Barker and Tammany's Fernando Wood factions push and pull at one another as they wedge their polls.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: He's got the right to vote, damn you!

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Not four times he don't. (shoves a Voter) There'll be no damned repeaters here! The Cop and Jimmy play tug-of-war with a besotted VOTER, members rush to GRAB VOTERS leaving the polls. PANDEMONIUM.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TAMMANY HALL DAY
dialogues.text: The main floor is jammed with CLUBMEN and PARTY RACKS. Da bustles from group to group, making promises, taking note out Boss Tweed, who is holding court in a far corner, sur JOURNALISTS.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I would never speak ill of a rival. I would never say tha Know-Nothing is a horse thief. It is my observation, howe horse thief is a Know-Nothing. Good-natured LAUGHING all around. Even TWEED seems amused catches the Boss' eye and whispers to him.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: The Know-Nothings are already finished, and there's four polls yet.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Keep our men voting. Everybody works today. It's not a vi Daniel. I want a triumph.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DON WHISKERANDOSO BARBER SHOP DAY
dialogues.text: Amsterdam roughly deposits REPEAT VOTERS in the barber ch BARBERS work FRANTICALLY to cut their hair, prune beards, alter appearances. As soon as one customer is done, Sheen with bay rum and pushes another REPEATER down in his plac count of the turnover.

dialogues.speaker: DON WHISKERANDOS, (BARBER)
dialogues.text: Now that's eight... and how many still to come ... He looks toward the door, where more Repeaters are lined turn under close supervision.

dialogues.speaker: REPEATER
dialogues.text: I already voted once today. Cast for Tammany, by God, and

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Once? Come here and do your duty. Amsterdam GRABS him and SLAMS him down in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FAN-TAN PARLOR DAY
dialogues.text: Amsterdam and some RABBITS BURST into the front door, fri scattering all the Chinese GAMBLERS.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (barking orders) Line up like soldiers!

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: They got no notion what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (To Johnny) You explain their democratic right. Illl see they unterst Amsterdam GRABS the nearest two CHINESE by their PIGTAILS HURLS them against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amsterdam and the Rabbits PROWL the murky darkness where in bunks stacked high against the walls. The Rabbits star rounding up the Opium Eaters. Jimmy Spoils SLINGS a coupl shoulder like flour sacks. Amsterdam SHOVES two more out admiring Daniel Killoran.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) I come to see if our counts square. You boys have made a showing....

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Who the hell's this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He's our Tammany man. Killoran compares his figures to the piece of paper where keeping his own count.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: ... remarkable...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (With an edge) Our own Tammany man. We are coming along. Happy to meet a Johnny Siroccols.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Likewise. Pleasure to meet the best but one in the whole

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Best but one? Who's better? Killoran looks up. Johnny, standing behind Amsterdam, SHA VIGOROUSLY. Killoran gets the message.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: (smooth) Maybe nobody. But when the count's done the numbers will out in front.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'm in no race. Just pay us what you owe.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Tonight. At the victory celebration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Tammany victory celebration. When we last saw this plac confronted Happy Jack--the place was busy, alive. It's RI to bursting with POLITICIANS, CRIMINALS, GANG MEMBERS, MO HANGERS-ON, UPTOWN THRILL-SEEKERS, JOURNALISTS and COPS, off duty. The SOUND of the place is a cacophony of SHOUTI GAMBLING and STRANGE MUSIC--which we can't identify at fi CLOSE on a huge ruby ring and we HEAR...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read what it says there, alongside the ruby...read it out ... and WE MOVE OUT as a WELL-WISHER reads the Latin insc

dialogues.speaker: WELL-WISHER
dialogues.text: "Fortuna Juvat Ordentes."

dialogues.speaker: TWEED
dialogues.text: A grand victory gift from the men of Tammany. Now, tell ' Mayor Wood.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: "Fortune favors the bold." TWEED gives him a resounding slap on the back.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: What do you think? Would that make a fit motto for our fa

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Well, I could certainly see ...

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We've got a motto.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: what is it? (no one knows) Well, hell, let's get one we can remember. We're going to hall, we better have something to put over the front door you'll make sure the Latin's right? As Wood nods his assent, CAMERA MOVES across room... ... past the gilded CAGES suspended ten feet over the flo women and children look down at the action just below the of trepidation and resignation. Occasionally a REVELER wi and GRAB one of the caged inhabitants. Still MOVING, CAME ... passes a stage, where we finally SEE the source of al MUSIC we've been hearing: the music is provided by CHINESE MUSICIANS, a woman SINGER, a DANCER and some ACRO perform some weird, mangled Five Points version of Chines music and performance continues as we MOVE PAST... ... across a PEWTER FAN-TAN TABLE, where CHINESE GAMBLERS animation and concentration. By comparison, the Occidenta beside them seem like tourists. Everyone SHOUTS and SCRAMBLES to place bets with the FAN- Above the Dealer is an oval opening in the ceiling, throu PLAYERS may watch the action below. These FAN-TAN PLAYERS elegantly carved rail, peering at the action on the table their bets and collecting their winnings by means of a BA WIRES that whirrs constantly overhead. We continue to MOV ... until we are at the door of the place, where Amsterda Rabbits are having words with a BOUNCER.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: I don't know you, you don't enter.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (enjoying himself) Come on, what are you saying? If you don't know us now, y tomorrow and you'll be working for us next week.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (more temperate) Daniel Killoran knows us.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: Oh he does?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: We work for him.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: The hell we do.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (to Amsterdam) Tampen down, will you?

dialogues.speaker: BOUNCER
dialogues.text: Why don't you all get the hell out of here and go fix on He SHOVES Johnny, who STUMBLES back into Amsterdam. They' and they step forward together toward the Bouncer... ... until Killoran intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: (to Bouncer) It's all right, Nat. They're saying the truth. They gave for a good wage. Killoran HANDS OVER a paper-wrapped parcel of money, whic firmly.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: A fine first showing. But second best.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Second, eh? You don't say so.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: It's no shame to be bested by veterans. The Native Americ the field.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: We count on them sure as mass comes an Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (to Johnny, glaring) Did you know this? Is this some scheme of yours?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No, I didn't have no idea ...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I was working the same side as the Natives? The Natives?

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: That's only right. Bill the Butcher's our ambassador thro Points, as you might say. It's deemed an honor to work wi knows Bill Poole, everyone fears him, everyone ...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I sure as hell don't fear him. And I sure as hell won't s any who calls him one of theirs.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Well, if it's matter of personal honor, the money can onl insult. I have no wish to rile you further, so if you'll He REACHES to take back the parcel of money, but Amsterda away.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Where is he? Where's Bill the Butcher?

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Listen, buck. This is a Tammany night. If you and Bill Po to settle, you can do it any other time, any other place, good dancing goddamn. But you do it here tonight and all will be down on you like the righteous wrath of heaven. o the Book says, put away childish things. Join the celebra I always find the least strenuous solution the most appea Amsterdam stares at him as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a CHINESE ACROBAT TWIRLS in the air, off the stage, an middle of the audience. The crowd is raucously appreciati does GYMNASTIC MOVES among them... ... past a table where the Dead Rabbits have settled. it evening, and everyone has been drinking. Amsterdam, sullen, intense, WATCHES ... ..Bill the Butcher, across the room. He is like a prince pays him court, including several uniformed COPS, TAMMANY NEWSPAPERMEN. Bill receives the attention as his due.... ... while Amsterdam keeps watching, contempt and hatred g eye. He pays attention to none of the gang around, includ takes advantage of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I got experience. It's the education I lack.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: And you heard I was a good teacher?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't listen to talk, I figure for myself. And I figure at everything you did.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And tonight I got the ned.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: And now what?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now I'm ready for you. Unless there's an arrangement betw Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (glancing over at Amsterdam) Not to my thinking.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (needs to be sure) Amsterdam... listen up, Amsterdam... Amsterdam glances over at them.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) You going with me or him? It's my thinking matters here. ask him nothing.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (makes his decision) How's the evening passing?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Fine. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (puts his arm around Jenny) 'Cause it's treating me fine too. She gets up and starts toward the stairs to the second fl following her, holding her hand. As they pass Amsterdam h Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: This is no game, you and me. Don't go on like it's a game

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I said already, it's not a game. It's business. Johnny pulls her away. As he watches her go through the c gaze falls on Bill the Butcher again... ... and for the first tine their EYES MEET. Bill's eyes r take him all in... but DON'T REMEMBER him. He looks away steps up to pay court.... .... and a MASTER OF REVELS, center-floor, SHOUTS ...

dialogues.speaker: MASTER OF REVELS
dialogues.text: Gentlemen and gentlewomen, if you please ... we will now. cages and start the bidding! The Crowd CHEERS and KIDS PULL on a series of ropes and p the CAGES further above the floor until they are parallel second-floor gallery of the Pagoda. WOMEN AND MEN call ou the cages rise through the air. Depending on their age, t children inside the cages respond to the auction with gri trepidation or fear. A few, drugged or drunk on all-sorts in their impossibly cramped space. Johnny and Jenny make their way along the second floor ga spots a COUPLE LEAVING a room and walks inside. Johnny CL behind them as a BURST of APPLAUSE... ... rises from the main floor, where Bill the Butcher sta center of the room. He slowly removes his coat and hands He is wearing his battle vest underneath, and it is fully his butcher's implements. The place QUIETS. KIDS swarm silently, like busy ants, al wooden CHANDELIER, LIGHTING its HUNDREDS of CANDLES. Only the Chinese playing fan-tan in the far corner of the room The Kids finish lighting the candles and the chandelier i the Pagoda ceiling, casting the whole place into a new ri SHADOW as The Butcher prepares himself. Now the Chinese Opera DANCER steps forward and stands nea The unsprung MUSIC begins. The DANCER starts to move, sin ...and Bill, with amazing skill, starts THROWING his KNIV MISSES the Dancer by a hairsbreadth, landing in the floor She doesn't flinch. She keeps dancing. And Bill keeps THR ... the KNIVES, which follow the Dancer around the room i deadly choreography. They land just inches from where she or will be: in a wall; a pillar; the apron of the small s the barrel of all-sorts. After each knife LANDS, kids ret one of the KNIFE KIDS pulls the blade from the all-sorts knock each other over to drink from the stream that flows Native Americans, meanwhile, WORK THROUGH the awed, atten AVOID Cops, Tammany Members and anyone who looks too pros sober. But when one of the Natives SPOTS a MARGINAL CITIZ hand and examine it as if they were telling fortunes. Center floor, Bill pulls TWO KNIVES out, BALANCES one in ... as a WHORE in the crowd pushes a guy who's groping he of Natives. Hels wearing a large RING. As soon as the Nat they throw their arms around the GROPER like a long-lost him to Bill ... ... who THROWS both knives rapidly at the Dancer. They la inches from her dancing feet. She SPINS AWAY to great app Natives bring the Groper to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Evening, sir. Are you prepared to be celebrated? Are you famous?

dialogues.speaker: GROPER
dialogues.text: How much will it cost?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Just a moment of your time. My men will assist you. They do quite a bit more than that: they GRAB the Groper the floor. In the crowd, one SPECTATOR turns to his compa

dialogues.speaker: PAGODA SPECTATOR
dialogues.text: Watch this careful. I've never seen the like, not even in The Groper CRIES OUT as the Natives PIN HIM to the floor, Bill has one weapon left... in a special pocket, inside h CLEAVER. He takes it out slowly, SAVORING the moment. The Pagoda goes QUIET. Only the gambling continues. The M only SOUND beside the noises of the Chinese at their fan- Groper, who HOLLERS for help as soon as he sees the cleav Bill HEFTS the cleaver in his hand, feels its weight, cal figures distance .... and starts THROWING it in the air.. ... CATCHING it by the handle ... then throwing it again. and HARDER with every toss.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (in full control) What's it so quiet for? I don't need quiet. The Chinese opera MUSIC commences with a dissonant CRASH. ... and Bill catches the cleaver again. But EVERY TIME he every time he catches it by its handle ... ... he also MOVES CLOSER to the terrified Groper. Now... very close... he gives the cleaver a mighty toss ... ... sending it SPINNING high in the air... up past the ca second-floor gallery, jammed with appreciative spectators SLOWS ... seems to HANG in the air... then starts its des ... FALLING FASTER... towards Bill's waiting, STEADY HAND The Groper SCREAMS in fear. Bill SMILES confidently, hold until ... just as smoothly, just as confidently... ... he PULLS his hand AWAY and the cleaver FALLS with ter the SPLAYED HAND of the Groper, cleanly SEVERING it at th Groper FAINTS dead away as a TREMENDOUS CHEER greets Bill One of the Natives TOSSES Bill the severed hand. Bill SLIDES the ring off the finger and TOSSES it to the

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: There's for your beauty and your song. The Dancer puts the ring on her finger and DANCES OFF. Bi hand to the floor and walks back to his table. The Crowd compliments on his dexterity, and the Knife Kids reverent Butcher's implements. Now two DOGS from the rat pit in the back room RUN throug FIGHT FRENZIEDLY over possession of the bloody hand. The Crowd PASSES the Groper overhead and WE SEE from ABOV unconscicus BODY being passed from hand to hand. The Crow wave bearing the body toward the door. The Groper's stump as he passes overhead, sprinkling drops of blood and fles sacrament. Bill approaches his table, acknowledging the continuing a about to sit down when a VOICE rises above all others.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Mr. Poole! Bill turns, searching out the voice ...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Bill Poole! And SEES Amsterdam, standing at his own table. His attitu smiling, respectful. But his eyes are demonic.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: My compliments on your exhibition, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It was like watching a dance. (Bill nods his thanks) Some great grand goddamned dance. (Bill looks at him more You know me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Do I? Are you missing a finger? Appreciative laughter from the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No. A father. The laughter turns a little uneasy. Bill the Butcher size man.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Do you have a name?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: That's a New York name. (suddenly smiles) shall we drink to it?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Indeed. (they drink) And to my other name. Vallon. Will you drink to that?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Priest Vallon's son? (Amsterdam nods) Of course I'll drink to that. Your father was a worthy ma

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Not worthy of you. Those dogs ain't worthy of you. You ai they feed on, and what they shit's too good for you. DEAD QUIET. Absolute. Breathless. Only the Chinese Gamble fan-tan ignore this confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: What do you want, boyo?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I got to give you something, Butcher. Something from my f Amsterdam PULLS OUT the piratels knife which Bill the But his father almost 12 years before.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You got the sand to draw a blade in front of me? You will Come ahead and give it here, you son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Amsterdam THROWS the knife, the bright blade FLASHING like lightning. And just as quickly the Buitcher PICKS UP his table, send flying and breaking, using it as a SHIELD... ... and the knife THUMPS into it dead center. The Butcher at Amsterdam...sending PATRONS yelling and SCATTERING. Amsterdam LEAPS out of the way of the table, then RUNS AT Butcher... ... who's already coming for him. As they CLASH and GRAPP other... ... PATRONS all over the Pagoda crowd around for a good v and start to MAKE BETS on the outcome. The odds do not fa And neither does the fight. Amsterdam fights with real bl doesn't have the Butcher's skill, or experience, or dispa the Butcher's CLINCH... HITS him once in the face... then ... and then gets FLOORED by a well placed kick. The Crow And, on the second floor, Jenny and Johnny come out of th arranging her clothes, Jenny looks over the gallery rail below, sees the fight... and starts to RUN down the stair her go ... looks at the fight again, for a second... then the main floor. The Butcher is on top of Amsterdam now. He HITS him upsid the wood and brass handle of his cleaver. Then hits him a In the Crowd now, Jenny finds Sheeny Mike.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: The Butcher'll kill him if we don't do something.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: It was Amsterdam's own doing. And it'll be our death too it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (finally catching up) That's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: The truth is you don't give a damn about him.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, if he gave a damn about us he wouldn't have c Butcher in the first place. Jenny looks at him with contempt, then STARTS into the cr her ARM but she pushes him off. On the floor, Bill uses the FLAT SIDE of the cleaver to S conscious Amsterdam on one side of his face... then on th REPEATEDLY... until Amsterdam is barely sensible. Bill gr hair. Amsterdam's body is slack.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: What do you say? Loin or shank? Rib or chop? The Crowd YELLS their choices. Jenny tries to PLUNGE thro Amsterdam, but a HALF-DOZEN MORTS and WHORES put hands on back.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Come on, let me hear you! (the Crowd yells louder) You're all talking at once, I can't hear you! (a near frenzy) I don't hear the choicest cut! The best, the vital! (they quiet a little to listen) The heart. I think I must have the heart! This is greeted with the biggest CHEER of the night. The Mayor Wood seems to feel as if he should do something to slaughter, but Boss Tweed calms him with a single dismiss the Boss himself is excited by the prospect of this ritua

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Come on, look at it! You fancy yourself a gladiator, act (raises his cleaver) Watch the death blow when it comes to you. Go to hell wit Bill the Butcher readies himself to deliver the blow... a his wrist, STOPPING his arm. Who would dare do this to Bill the Butcher? Bill turns, i look into... ... the untroubled face of Monk Eastman.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: It's been a full evening's fun now, Butcher. It's enough.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You got nothing to do with this, Monk.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMKN
dialogues.text: Well I'm the game warden, you might say. I'm telling you young yet. Wait till he's aged for a proper kill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: The hell. With his gigantic strength, Monk actually PULLS the Butch and onto his feet.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMKN
dialogues.text: Just settle yourself Bill ... ... and he part SHOVES, part THROWS Bill back a good twen

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMKN
dialogues.text: ... and let the merrymaking continue. The Dead Rabbits have scampered forward, and they're pick off the floor. Monk looks at Jenny and Johnny, who each h an arm.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: It was his father took me in first, and it's thanks I'm r

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Eastman!

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: (ignoring Bill) This squares any debt. Get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Monk Eastman! As the Rabbits CARRY Amsterdam toward the door, Monk fina attention back to Bill.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'll have you then!

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Come ahead, Bill. Unless you're wanting to shout me to de And Bill comes forward, BRANDISHING his cleaver. Monk Eas ground, unmoving, untroubled. Everyone looks on in awe at ... except Boss Tweed.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (to Killoran) If these two are going to combat, it aught to be a worthi more rewarding for all. Tweed SIGNALS to Bill: STOP. The Butcher sees the signal it. He SHAKES his head. His blood is up. He won't stop. Tweed SIGNALS AGAIN. Bill KEEPS COMING. Tweed signals Killoran, who STANDS himself. And, when he and TAMMANY LOYALIST in the place--a hundred of them anyw Boss Tweed. As Bill keeps coming, and Monk stands easy, waiting... ... the Natives and their ALLIES now stand, facing the Ta Tammany backers, dressed flush and fancy, face the scruff Five Points bunch: the twin factions of the criminal unde different in style and so similar in purpose, SIZE EACH O opposite sides of the room. Bill STOPS. The odds are shifting, the stakes are climbin Chinese STOP GAMBLING. For the first time all evening the absolutely STILL. Even the Dead Rabbits have turned, at t what will happen. Tweed and the Butcher LOCK EYES: neither blinks. Then aft very long moment ... a calm, bemused Tweed RAISES his gla

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I only wanted to thank you, Bill, for the customary good an equally bright future for us both. Another pause. Bill does not look placated. The whole pla explode... ... until Boss Tweed RISES to his feet, and RAISES his gl

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Will you drink with me, Bill, as a friend? An honored fri Bill weighs the proposition... then looks to his men, NOD call them off. He GRABS a glass off a table to join Tweed The MUSIC begins again. The gambling recommences. Patrons seats. The Dead Rabbits help Amsterdam out the door. Monk Eastman sidles up to Bill the Butcher.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I can't abide, it's fighting for fre He takes the Butcher's glass from his hand, raises it in DEEP and hands it back to him. At the door of the Pagoda, a badly beaten Ansterdam start fighting by brute instinct. He HITS Jenny, and she goes d grapples with him as Jenny PICKS HERSELF up and struggles Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Go easy! Go easy. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He knew what he was doing, hitting you.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Let's get him up. She grabs Amsterdam's arm and, with Johnny's help, tries to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (Looking at Amsterdam's bloody face) Therels too damn little of him left to know anything. They start across Paradise Square, holding him up... ... as the rest of the Dead Rabbits join to help them... smaller in the distance against the primeval nighttime la Five Points... ... and the Bouncer CLOSES the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DON WHISKERANDOS BARBER SHOP DAY
dialogues.text: Another DOOR OPENS, and Amsterdam stands on the threshold has passed since the big night at Sparrow's Pagoda, but A still shows the marks of Bill's beating. Don Whiskerandos is ministering to Monk Eastman with a st giving him a close and careful shave. Monk is thoroughly even glance over when the door opens, hardly reacts when says ....

dialogues.speaker: DON WHISKERANDOS
dialogues.text: Someone's here for you.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: That so? What's he look like?

dialogues.speaker: DON WHISKERANDOS
dialogues.text: He looks pretty damned sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: (looks at Amsterdam) Indeed.- Can I buy you a shave?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Face is too sore, eh? I understand.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No. I'm beholden enough to you as it is. I don't like to

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: We're all even, son. There's nothing more between us.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'd like it if there was.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Are you proposing employment?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: A collaboration. The Dead Rabbits got to get strong befor move. I figure you're the one to make us strong. There's learn from you.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Boyo, I'm a freebooter and a mercenary, not a teacher. I nothing from you and I can't earn nothing from you either

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: The Dead Rabbits is going to be glorious again. We're goi the Points.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: And Bill Poole's Natives? What will they have to say?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Nothing. They won't have tongues left to speak.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Don't worry about what theylll have in their mouths. You they got in their hands. (beat) Listen, son... take a word from a man who was honored to father. Temper yourself like a sword, and pay attention t spoils an edge.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Then you say no? Monk SIGHS and points to a huge WAR CLUB which hangs in a above the shop mirror. It has deep marks running along it

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: You see my instrument there? First notch represents two d cents. That's how much I got for my first kill. There are notches after it, and my fee has grown with each one. I c you alright, but you got to afford me. So do business wit your own.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Everything I got is still to come. So I guess it's on my

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Fair enough. You'll find independence a fine thing, a fie Although I do hold money preferable to all. (Amsterdam turns to leave) But I'm sure we'll have news of each other.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Bound to. As he shuts the door of the shop, Monk Eastman gestures t Whiskerandos for another hot towel.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREETS OFF PARADISE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: A large wagon bearing a Tammany banner and carrying dozen of coal moves slowly down the narrow street. Boss Tweed s seat, next to the driver, as his minions HAND him coal sa distributes them with a smile to the NEEDY who trot next

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (to the people as they grab the coal) Tammany's here to take the chill off the winter and the w heart. It's Tammany can make this city a fit place, with of all you good people... As he continues, Bill the Butcher JUMPS onto the wagon an beside him. Boss Tweed hardly gives him a glance.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You sent me word.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: We could use help here. Grab a sack.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I keep my hands clean.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (now he looks at him) So I've observed.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (tense) Better be on your mark to talk like that to me. It was yo the Pagoda. I would have cut Monk inside out.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: What if you hadn't? Think of the embarrassment. And what Consider the waste. Next time you're in a dust-up like th and make proper plans. It'd be a grand source of revenue,

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: It touches my heart how you always. have our best interes

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Our mutual interests. That's why I want you to contact Mo (Bill's incredulous) I want you to extend a proposition. I want him to join US

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Oh, not Tammany, of course not. We could no more have him But he should throw in with the Native Americans, become Arrangement and ... well, use his influence, shall we say all.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You're saying I can't do everything you need? You don't t has been doing good and right? You think there's somethin that I ...

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (interrupting) It's none of that, Bill. None of that. His independence i to Tammany. And an insult to you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Then you should have let me have him at Sparrow's.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I should. If I'd been confident-absolutely certain--that prevailed. Monk is an unpredictable power, and a figure o to be reckoned with.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: He needs to be killed.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: No. He's an elemental force. Them you don't destroy. But them and use them for the good they give off. He hands Bill a sack of coal.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Coal? Bill doesn't answer. He HOPS DOWN off the moving wagon, a way quickly before him, then regroup and SWARM after Twee The Boss continues with his Tammany spiel-enjoying all th the Butcher watches, disdainful of Tweed but filled with frustration. From his face we ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. DON WHISKERA.NDOS BARBER SHOP DAY
dialogues.text: ... the incredulous face of Monk Eastman, as he looks at

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: And this is your offer?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: It's Boss Tweedls offer.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: How do you think we'd sit as allies, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: The only way we could tolerate being near each other woul out dead.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: My thoughts exactly. Then why are you here? Because you w You were ordered to be. And who would order me among the would you follow my orders, even if they was being relaye Marcy Tweed himself? He EASES himself out of the barber chair. The Butcher TEN toward him.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Dubious and doubtful, my friend. But your offer--pardon, bring--is the most generous that's ever been extended. I if not the personalities. So let us decide the way any Na would appreciate. We'll do it the democratic way. He throws open the door of the barber shop and stands the the Butcher, his arm thrown carelessly around him. PASSER wonderment as Monk ADDRESSES them.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Citizens of the Five Points! It seems the Native American trouble. They have grown so weak that now they seek my he any wage I ask. But I ask you now. Even for money, should conspire alongside a boyo like this with gristle on his k on his chin every time his cock gets hard? Monk is beaming, the Butcher is appalled. His body tenses ready to spring. But the people in the street just STARE- believe what they've just heard.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: (to Bill) There. You see. I'm afraid the people have spoken.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'll see you again, you bog Irish bastard.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Well, if it's a fight you want now, Bill, remember to com bankroll. Monk returns to the shop and the comfort of his chair. Bi people in the street. One lock from him starts them movin do not look away from him quite so fast, or at him, eithe same fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vast main room has been changed into a dance floor an the evening. An altar has been hung with bunting; SHIP'S CANDLES illuminate the place. The REVEREND SHADRACH RALEI everyone. The room, already crowded with CELEBRANTS of al quiet as the Dead Rabbits, done up in their party best, s revelry.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Ah, the Native Americans, is it now?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Are they coming?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: We don't want a ruckus, minister.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Nor do I. I intended no disrespect. I'd heard the Native figures of the greatest prominence here.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Indeed they are, just for the moment. Let them come. Happ Everyone's welcome in a house of God, isn't that right, R

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: As all are welcome in heaven.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: Ild like to go to heaven. Ild like to go to heaven and bi ear.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: You're still welcome, even with such peculiar appetites.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: But if the Natives do come, Father...

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: I'm not a priest, son ...

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: ... there's no accounting for what may follow.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: I'm sure God's hand will guide us in that. Just as He gui the right perfect time, with a right perfect regent. The the sunset hair. Miss ...

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Everdeane. Jenny Everdeane.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Miss Everdeane. Step forward, please. Radiant and curious, Jenny joins the Reverend Raleigh in room.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: And the evening's regent chooses her evening's partner. There is much MUTTERING about this from everyone. Someone farting SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: REVERAND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: (unfazed) Here we make only joyful noises to the Lord. Under the instruction of the bustling Reverend and his HE skeptically stand away from the Men, who allow themselves into a LINE. The Reverend Raleigh escorts the delighted J that has been placed, by itself, in the center of the roo down, facing away from the rest of the guests. She holds hand.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Now. The men, please. One by one. The first volunteer Reverend Raleigh brings forward is a Mike. There are RUDE COMMENTS as he leads Mike slowly to room, coming up behind Jenny until she can see Mikels fac the mirror. She SHAKES her head.

dialogues.speaker: REVEREND RALEIGH
dialogues.text: Next Gentleman, please. More laughing. The BOYS push out one CANDIDATE. Rejected. Now ANOTHER CANDIDATE comes forward. And STILL ANOTHER- J with the composure of a princess. Now it is Johnny's turn. He WALKS slowly across the big r behind Jenny, trying to look confident. The moment is lon tense... until--just once but very decisively-Jenny SHAKE Jenny watches Johnny's face in the mirror. She stays stil walks back to the GANG. Now Amsterdam starts toward the center of the room. He ke fixed on Jenny. Jenny catches Amsterdam's reflection in the mirror. He ST head. Yes. Him. A small BAND strikes up a barely recognizable version of Fortress Is Our God," arranged in waltz time. Jenny rises her arms to Amsterdam. They start to DANCE, a little clum COUPLES join them.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: So you accept?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You accept to be my mort and no one else's.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (teasing) No, it's just that I didn't recognize you in the mirror. some of the face the Butcher gave you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (going along with the joke) It's not the Butcher, it's the dancing. It shifts my face

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll look better later. The Reverend Raleigh and his Helpers DASH among the dance LIGHTED CANDLES, which the COUPLES take and hold as they floor.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I will if we're together later. (she smiles) And what about after that? After tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I chose you just for tonight. If that's not good enough I someone else. She takes a candle from the Reverend and holds it so the Amsterdam's face.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'll have tonight. But after this don't come to me no mor ready. No more. His eyes, in the candlelight, show both his love and his NODS and they DANCE AWAY ... ... losing themselves now among the dancers, all moving a candles. As they dance, their movement becomes SPLIT, SEQ in motion like an old Gjon Mili photograph. Their bodies YELLOW LIGHT ACROSS the screen like the tail of a comet.

dialogues.speaker: INT- DEAD RABBITS HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: In the hallway. JOHNNY stands pressed against a door.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (whispering) Amsterdam. (louder; hissing) Amsterdam!

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't want to come in! You come out.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Just a damn minute. AMSTERDAM comes to the door, half-dressed and sleepy. We on the floor inside.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PIER/DEAD RABBITS HOUSE NIGHT
dialogues.text: Just before dawn. The streets are empty, the river is qui follows JOHNNY out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I'm going to fight you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, Johnny, I'm tired. How about sometime else?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You want to tell me what this fight's over? Is it The But (Johnny turns, determined) Alright, alright. Then tell me why like this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: So when I lose no one will see. And he SLUGS him. Hard. Harder even than he thought he co stumbles, stunned, then pulls himself up. And CHARGES at him down. The two friends PUNCH, WRESTLE, BITE and PUMMEL EACH OTHE extravagant energy that they soon... ... ROLL OFF the pier...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PIER DAWN
dialogues.text: ... onto the muddy ground underneath the pier. They LAND SPLASH in the soggy earth, but they keep fighting .... ... as a PACK OF ORPHANS, eyes glinting like night animal wild beasts disturbed in their burrow. Amsterdam has the physical advantage, and more skill. But fury. All the feeling and the frustration rain out of him making the match nearly even. The Orphan Pack watches the fight silently, showing no fa emotion, just an edge of curiosity. Amsterdam HITS Johnny a wicked combination that makes him in the mud. But Johnny will not go down. Amsterdam, hurt stares at Johnny in wonderment.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Satisfied?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Satisfied? It wasn't me that's been dancing and shagging And he pulls himself to his feet and THROWS a roundhouse half-staggers out of the way. The moment throws Johnny of falls in the mud again, this time on all fours. Amsterdam beside him.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Enough. Johnny won't stop: he throws a punch that Amsterdam can s away. But he's too tired too duck; or maybe he's just fed punch and FALLS on his back.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: That's it then.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: The hell. And he THROWS HIMSELF on Amsterdam. It's more like he rol than anything, but he's on top of him now, hitting him in all he's got left in him.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Goddamn it. Amsterdam HEAVES Johnny off and pops him a solid SWIPE to does it. Lights out. Johnny falls unconscious into the sl pier. The Orphan Pack keeps staring from the shadow with their Still silent. Amsterdam STRUGGLES to his feet, stops at t to get a handful of water to revive himself. Then he look unconscious friend.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Goddamn you anyway. He grabs Johnny's body by the shoulders and pulls him to He gets some water on his hand, lets it drip over Johnny' away a little of the blood. Not enough. He draws some mor it gently onto Johnny's face. CLOSE: on the motion of his hand. It is nearly gentle.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DON WHISKERANDOS BARBER SHOP DAY
dialogues.text: As Don Whiskerandos' hand, holding a razor, travels over of Monk Eastman's face. His hand is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: What's the trouble, Don?

dialogues.speaker: DON WHISKERANDOS
dialogues.text: There's someone here. Monk bestirs himself in the chair, SEES: Bill the Butcher doorway.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: It's just a man of commerce. Monk settles back in the chair as Bill the Butcher walks

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You're right enough this time, Monk. (to Don Whiskerandos) Go ahead. (the barber hesitates) Go on with your work. I'll finish my business. Don Whiskerandos picks up a pair of SCISSORS and NERVOUSL Monk's hair.

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: Come out with it then. Bill NODS emphatically at Don Whiskerandos, who is clearl nods again, almost vehemently. Don Whiskerandos SHAKES hi GLARES at him. The Barber takes a STEP BACK. Monk opens h to size up the situation.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You damn craven, do it! Bill LEAPS forward, grabs the trembling barber's arm and MONK...

dialogues.speaker: MONK EASTMAN
dialogues.text: (rising from his chair) What the hell... ...and the scissors, held by Don Whiskerandos and pushed Butcher, meet Monk full in the face as he bolts from the scissor BLADE SINKS into Monkls right eye. MONK BELLOWS, staggers toward Don Whiskerandos, who shrin wall. The scissor protrudes from Monk's eye as he RAGES, now reaching out for the Butcher

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Your eyes was open for that alright. And you still got on Bill the Butcher reaches above him for Monk's war club, w wall. He grabs tight hold of it and, with Monk nearly upo viciously at Monk's head. The BLOW sends the scissor FLYI eye, with the eyeball still attached. It also SMASHES in Monk's face. He FALLS, still GRABBING desperately for the ... who now stands over him, beating him incessantly with CAVING his head in. KILLING him. Don Whiskerandos looks at Bill in a virtual paralysis of Butcher lets the CLUB FALL, reaches in his pocket and thr the barber.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: If I was you I'd use that to open in a new location. Cons The enormity of what he's done is beginning to sink in. H the shop ... but STOPS in the doorway. Outside, CITIZENS of the Points are staring at the fallen wonder. They have just witnessed a moment in history. Bill the Butcher surveys them all silently, then calls ou Whiskerandos.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: The war club. The barber steels himself to CARRY the bloody club to the hefts it slowly in his hands, in view of all. He takes a knife from his vest, and CUTS the LAST NOTCH i slowly... ... he steps down into the crowd, which PARTS before him. walks among them in regal splendor, the war club at his s gore. As the crowd falls back, Bill spots Amsterdam, Johnny and other Dead Rabbits, watching his every mave. He STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLDS OUT the bloody war club in front of him... straight him... POINTING IT right at Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I promise you, Amsterdam. I promise you. Then he grins, turns away and walks through the crowd: pr surveys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boss Tweed reigns in the banquet room of a vast, gaslit r long table overburdened with food. Seated along both side an array of the city's POWER BROKERS, with whom Tweed and MINIONS mix easily. Their attitude toward the Power Broke of ribald fawning and fine condescension; the Power Broke enjoy the food, and the MUSIC from a small BAND, and the flirt and entertain them, while exuding the unmistakable amateur anthropologists exploring a decaying civilization Tweed is courting and joking with a bewhiskered HORACE GR the influential Tribune.

dialogues.speaker: GREELEY
dialogues.text: I may enjoy the bounty of your table and the pleasures of Mr. Tweed ...

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: And the pleasures of the company provided you, Mr. Greele

dialogues.speaker: GREELEY
dialogues.text: ...without the Tribune endorsing your politics.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I suppose you can at that. Take with one hand, flay with Virtuels on your conscience, Horace, but Tammany's in you Killoran materializes at Tweed's side and whispers someth discreetly in his ear. Tweed EXCUSES himself, rises quick across the restaurant floor... ... past the Band and the Dancing Giris ... ... to the swinging doors of the kitchen. As he pushes op DOOR, his face has lost its humor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A madhouse of activity. WAITERS in black suits, vests and STREAM by carrying huge TRAYS of food while the KITCHEN S double-time to keep up with the unceasing volume. As Boss Tweed walks in, Bill the Butcher PLUCKS a piece o off a tray as it's carried out the door.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'm not good enough for your table, so I eat where I can. bite) It's good, what is it?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Pheasant.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Is that like pigeon? I killed a pigeon once but it didn't like this.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: You killed a bull this morning. I told you to make an Arr him, and you come back with his blood on your hands.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (chewing his food) He insulted me. He aggravated me. I couldn't stand for th

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: You stand for anything if I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You think I should be afraid of you. You act like lightni you talk. As they talk, and the tension builds between them, the tw constantly BUFFETED by the swinging doors and the unendin WAITERS.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I never was afraid of you, so don't think I was or act li ain't earned it.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: What did you earn us, killing Monk?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Where'd you earn the right to ask that question? You rais the streets a while back, but no more. You got power but muscle and you ain't got a notion what it means to be a w

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I see it lost you a lot of God's sense, along with that e

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You don't know nothing about that! It was my doing! It sa "If thy eye offend thee, pluck it out." I followed that l knife and hand. The first I ever fought Priest Vallon, he when he came to bring me to death, I looked away and he w let me go. The shame was worse than the killing. I would eyes if I could still have fought, but cutting just the o When I killed Priest Vallon, that restored me. Now I sent over I got glory. I got all there is, and small thanks to

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (measured, conciliatory) You need two eyes to see the dep how we help each other. If it wasn't for me would be happ plunder the Points and put the fear into people who don't else. But Bill, I'm only saying... I'm counselinm... look You want to sit at my table, fine. But you must always re host is. It's not a matter of courage welre talking. It's Bill grabs another piece of food from a tray.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Howls these manners?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Fine, if you're hungry.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'm always hungry.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I've always told you, Bill. There's plenty for all, and m together than separate. We'll dine together sometime. Bill the Butcher nods, appeased, and leaves, swaggering h the kitchen chaos, making everyone get out of his way. Bo him go, his expression changing from bemused appeasement

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Everyone's gone except some WAITERS, cleaning up, and Daniel Killoran, who sit at the end of the banquet ta plates of food have been massed at Tweedls place and, as PICKS from them.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Let me put this to you, Daniel. Now that the Butcher has most prominent figure in the Five Points--a man of myth a there to take his place? (as Killoran starts to answer) Of course. Then what do we do about the Butcher? He's too killed, but he must be checked.

dialogues.speaker: KILLARAN
dialogues.text: It could be a police matter.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Impossible! Any cops who might have the mettle to go agai have blood ties to the gangs. They can't be trusted. And be trusted are too craven to be any use. If Bill's to be come from within the Points, not without.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: The Dead Rabbits did a proud job for elections. That Amst sand.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: That so? The last time I saw him he was under the Butcher like a fine filet. Who else is there?

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Well, the Rough and Tumble Boys over to Slaughterhouse Po Country McCleesterls bunch, too, and the Plug Uglies, but that have the promise of the Dead Rabbits, or the stake,

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: What would that be?

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: The boy Amsterdam has a blood feud with the Butcher. He's for the death of his father, and he's got the heart to ca He'll have the skill and power soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Blood will make a man intrepid. Bring them along, then. N Rabbits with neglect. Let them roam where they like.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: And if they roam into some portion of our own revenues?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I'd tolerate a little trespassing if it was for a higher They'll cross with the Natives soon enough and keep each

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: Bill's got to be a lot more than occupied.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I'll hold Bill in check. If he becomes unwieldy ... well, Daniel, I might just have to oil up my old musket. What d that, eh? Boss Tweed gets up from the table. A WAITER is DIMMING th filling the room with deep shadows.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: It'd be gratifying, Mr. Tweed. Even edifying.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: But poor politics, eh? Well, we musn't have that. (as he walks away) I do miss those roistering days, though. Oh, and bring so for the canaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sharply-angled turn of Doyers Street, nicknamed "The SOUND of a horse and cart as we see a row of UPTURNED mos YOUNG CHILDREN. A NATIVE AMERICAN drives a cart carrying large barrels of NATIVE rides beside him on the seat, holding a rifle, loo at the faces turned up to him. A WOMAN holding a BABY in CHILD by the hand steps in front of them. They almost run

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: We ain't had no milk this week.

dialogues.speaker: NATIVE 2
dialogues.text: You can have as much as you can pay for. (to crowd) Anyone that's got the ned, step up with your pitchers. An when you do. The Woman gives her children to other WOMEN in the crowd toward the wagon. Native 2 cocks his rifle... ... and Jenny steps from the watchful Crowd.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I got ned enough for all. See? Fair enough? She holds her hand out as she WALKS slowly toward the mil carrying a huge fistful of GLEAMING COINS. The Natives on her warily... ... and are JUMPED from behind by a couple of Dead Rabbit grabs a milk pitcher from a WOMAN in the crowd, AXES open milk barrel and FILLS the pitcher to overflowing. Jenny J wagon seat.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (to Amsterdam) What's our rate? What do we charge?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Johnny worked it out to a nickel less than the Natives. J established. Then we raise it a penny more than now.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Raise it? Is that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You say, then.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (beat; then, to Crowd) There'll be no paying at all this week, neither. This is Dead Rabbits business from now on. The Crowd scrambles for milk and the Rabbits try to keep

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (to Crowd) We'll take ned if you got it, now or in future. But no on

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (to Jenny) Except us. You opening a charity?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: They'll pay us what they owe, in loyalty if not in cash. coal, we give milk.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: They can afford it.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Can't we?

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTHER JOYCE'S BORDELLO DAY
dialogues.text: The midday sun shining through the windows makes the plac slightly desperate: this is a place that needs low light to look good. Amsterdam and Johnny are at a long bar, talking to Mother wised-up woman with pornographic tattoos an both forearms

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JOYCE
dialogues.text: This place is so clean it's the next thing to chaste. And convent, too.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: From the Natives, maybe. But not from us.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JOYCE
dialogues.text: You're saying I got to worry about your mob too?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: No worries at all. You throw in with the Dead Rabbits and about the Natives. Across the room, Jenny is sitting talking to a few of the whom is a mixed-blood Eurasian with long black hair named gets up lazily and heads for the bar. As she passes a DRU out to grab her. She's used to this, and she knocks his h keeps after her. At the bar, Mother Joyce notices Emma being hassled, but attention: her girls can take care of themselves.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JOYCE
dialogues.text: (to Amsterdam and Johnny) And if someone else comes along, do I pay them too?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You only pay us. We see you safe from everyone. Johnny has been watching the drunk bothering Emma Loss. W anything to Amsterdam or Mother Joyce, Johnny LEAVES the to the drunk and SHOVES him away.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Leave off her. She don't want you. Not even if you could

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: Hey, just a minute.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (to Emma) He can't pay. I can pay.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (watching this) Maybe I should offer Johnny as a bouncer for your busy ni

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JOYCE
dialogues.text: (laughs) A bouncer! I don't know if he could bounce on a feather b be a character like you, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: He's got his own ideas. Too full of Tammany, maybe, but h Across the room, Johnny is talking to Emma Loss. She NODS LEAD him upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JOYCE
dialogues.text: But in my trade you go on your instincts. My instincts sa and my memory of your father says I'm right. We'll shake (Amsterdam grabs her hand) And have one of my best to seal the bargain. Megs! A lanky blonde, seated across the room near Jenny, bestir

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER JOYCE
dialogues.text: Come here and show my new friend why we're worth special Jenny watches MEGS move toward Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big enough to contain a half-gutted mattress supported by some worn sheets and a few GUTTERING CANDLES. Johnny undresses as Emma sits on the bed and starts to ta

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You liked that old man? You would have gone with him?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: I like anyone that pays, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Tell me what he wanted you to do.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: He mostly wanted comforting.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I never seen hair so black. Can you take the pins out?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: It takes so long to do back up. He sits beside her and starts slowly, almost tenderly, to

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Did your mother have the same color? I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (as the hair cascades over her bare shoulders) Lie back, I want to look at you. (his eyes glide along her body) What's that mark?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: I always had it.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (touching her lightly) And there? Is that a scar?

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: (she looks at her naked belly) There was a baby. They cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: And that on your shoulder? That looks old.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: Yeah, I got that when I ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (interrupting, quiet) I don't want to know when. Don't tell me about before or be, I don't want that.

dialogues.speaker: EMMA LOSS
dialogues.text: What about your scars. Do you have scars?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: None I ever seen. Maybe you can find them. Her hands and mouth cover his body. He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another room. Amsterdam and Megs are undressing each othe walks in.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Go on. I can see you later. Megs leaves, brushing past Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I couldn't decline what Mother Joyce offered. It's in the business. You understand business.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Sure I do. But there's something else I still don't under Sparrow's Pagoda, did you hit me, knowing it was me?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Yeah. I did. She HITS him. In the face. Hard. Not a slap. A solid PUNC starts to gush blood. He puts his arm under it to staunch keeping his eyes an her.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Meantime's over.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Oh fine. That's fine. I'd be celebrating but I'm losing t Jenny tears part of the sleeve from her blouse and puts i nose.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Put your head back.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: That don't work.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Put your head back I said.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (as she tends to him) So why so sudden, then?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Sudden? Every day I see you and you complain I can't deci you say it's sudden.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It's the whore did it, then.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Don't flatter yourself.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It's because you're jealous.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It's because you didn't lie about hitting me.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Christ, I wish I had. Come here, then. He reaches to pull her down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Not here. There's too much past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room where Johnny fetched Amsterdam out for the fight Jenny have just made love.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It must be morning.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I don't care, I'm not getting up.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: This is what you meant, then? It's going to be just the s

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Every morning I wake up next to you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Or you don't wake up at all.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: We only just started in and you're already threatening me

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It's not a threat. (no teasing now) It's a declaration of love.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I prefer my kind. This kind. She reaches beneath the pillow and pulls out a fine DIAMO she slips on his finger. Amsterdam reacts with surprise, course) suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What's this? Where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You said I was the best thief in the Five Points. But I g restless. Will you wear something I got?

dialogues.speaker: EXT- UPTOWN STREET DAY
dialogues.text: A long street of tree-shaded houses. Spacious lawns. Nort Points. Considerably north. This is the first time we hav the Five Points and Paradise Square. The city rent place. Jenny and Amsterdam stand near a residence at the end of Amsterdam, dressed in a suit, can't quite conceal his won staring at the house.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What is this place?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: My jeweler's. She GESTURES for him to follow her and we see now that sh maid's outfit.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I don't see nobody.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: That's the best time. They're all having lunch.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UPTOWN HOUSE DAY
dialogues.text: At the back door of the grand house, as Jenny OPENS it sl inside.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You're off your head.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (pleased, showing off) You can wait on me a minute. Or I'll see you back in the scared. (Amsterdam looks at her) Don't worry. I know every house on this street. They all open. They live like they're not in New York. She GOES IN the house. Amsterdam WATCHES through the wind going up stairs. Then he looks at the dining room, visibl through an open kitchen door. He WATCHES, fascinated, fragments of the everyday rituals never seen. As SOUNDS drift listlessly from the street be BREEZE blows, WE SEE IN A SERIES OF DISSOLVES the serving SERVANTS carrying and passing plates; FAMILY MEMBERS reac and passing them; the LOW KURMUR of Konversation in accen heard. It's not so much that these people and their life him. It is as if he has stepped into another Dimension. He loses his sense of time, and of danger. So that when J arm she surprises him thoroughly.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Come on. I might still be taken for a maid. But you're no a butler.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. UPTOWN STREET DAY
dialogues.text: As Jenny and Amsterdam walk away from the house. She hold look young and full of hope, like a servant couple just o country enjoying a day off.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: The Police Commissioner lives the next street over. I was visiting him next month, but cops don't buy goods. They k graft in cash. Amsterdam looks at the houses with wonder that he tries t She opens her satchel a little way, then NUDGES him to ha swag inside.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: How's that for ten minutes?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It's a lot to fence.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I'm not going to fence it. I'm going to keep it and take will recognize it.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Where would that be?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Somewhere west. Far west. Past the Mississippi River, som territory.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: That's a hard journey for a woman alone.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You'd be with me.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You got it all planned and straight, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Once I said I'd be with you I wanted someplace we could b Someplace better than here. What's the matter with that?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Nothing. Except there's no place but here for me right no settle things.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know, but I'm talking about settling down, not se

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You don't have my obligations.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARADISE SQUARE DAY
dialogues.text: The Dead Rabbits SWEEP across the bustling square, Johnny the lead.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's a fair day's wage. We just move the people out of th collect.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Who from?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Who owns the building. (points) Them. The gang approaches a tumbledown BUILDING called Jacob's the iron rungs that run straight up its front to the roof well-dressed GENTS stare at the building fretfully.

dialogues.speaker: GENT 1
dialogues.text: (to Johnny) I'm glad you came in force. There's half a hundred people

dialogues.speaker: GENT 2
dialogues.text: Maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: GENT 1
dialogues.text: And not one's given rent the whole year.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You live here?

dialogues.speaker: GENT 1
dialogues.text: No, no, of course not.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I mean in the city. A ways north, I'll bet.

dialogues.speaker: GENT 2
dialogues.text: Yes. Why? A RIFLE SHOT sounds from an upper window and a Rabbit fal all DUCK FOR COVER.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It's not just citizens in there?

dialogues.speaker: GENT 1
dialogues.text: Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: with arms?

dialogues.speaker: GENT 2

dialogues.speaker: GENT 2

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: We didn't contract for that.

dialogues.speaker: GENT 1
dialogues.text: We'll pay extra for the danger.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No danger. But you will pay extra. (turns; to gang) Let's go and greet some Natives. Under SCATTERED RIFLE FIRE and a barrage of ROCKS, the GA building, charging inside and starting up the ladder as i attacking a medieval fortress. ARMS reach out from window them off. dialogues.text: Later. The same OVERHEAD ANGLE. BODIES litter the street dead and wounded Rabbits lie near NATIVES who have gone t Some BUILDING RESIDENTS wander the street in a daze. JOHN money from the Two Gents, who look very pleased as Amster with Jenny. He's carrying a rifle he took from the buildi

dialogues.text: (to Gents) Alright, then?

dialogues.text: Very much alright. Quite a spectacle.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Oh really? Just the entertainment you favor, is it? Pardo moment, gents. (he turns to Jenny) You wanted to settle, you and me. That's so, isn't it? Yo you not.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Good, because I didn't want to act hasty. I can never tel you're thinking, and sometimes I'm not always sure what y

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (to Gent 2) Excuse me. We'll conclude in a moment. (back to Jenny) Where do you settle?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Amsterdam, what are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'm asking, where does anyone settle?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I don't know, you mean a place, a home?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: A home yes.

dialogues.speaker: GENT 1
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but we really must conclude.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) Well, I'm saying to you then, Jenny Everdeane, welcome ho No one sees it coming. Amsterdam FLASHES around, swinging rifle into Gent l's midsection, doubling him over and sen breathless to the ground. Amsterdam SPINS again and swing Gent 2's face, knocking him cold.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Fine place. Room enough for all. (to Johnny) Get them out of here.

dialogues.speaker: GENT 2
dialogues.text: They'll come back looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: With whose help? The Natives? They won't help these flour even for ned. (to Jenny) Tell any who wants they can stay. If they can't pay rent gang. But make sure the best rooms go to us. Look around

dialogues.text: (interrupting) I know this building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jenny leads Amsterdam through a narrow tunnel. The pla weird catacomb: it is narrow and dank, filled with bones of the two- and four-legged variety.

dialogues.text: These lead all under the Square, into the Brewery and out there. They're closed off and forgotten since the Reveren mission. Pass me the candle. Amsterdam hands Jenny a stump of candle, which she holds see... ... that the tunnel has opened onto a small room just abo of Jacob's Ladder. It's a graveyard, memorializing gang m better world--or worse. Trophies from many gangs--includi skulls of some Dead Rabbits-litter the place in loose rit if this were a catacomb in Palermo. Stooping low, Jenny walks to a narrow corner of the room, PAVING STONES have been laid in the rough pattern of a cr slate serves as a headstone, and on it, in fading paint, is the name "Maggie Everdeane."

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: We lived in this building till she lost her seamstress wo the Brewery. One day she slept so drunk she never woke an back here. Dug this myself. (beat) Families. Give here what I gave you. Amsterdam hands her a chest that looks like a small versi Blackbeard's treasure box. She opens it and holds the can is the swag from all her cat burglaries. There's a lot of with promise in the GUTTERING flame. Jenny starts to dig grave.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: She'll keep an eye on this for us. How about some help? He KNEELS beside her and they dig at the grave with stone

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You trusting me with your treasure, then?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Just take another look at it to remind you. I can always Amsterdam reaches inside the chest, pulls out a ring and Jenny's dirt-covered finger. She KISSES him.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: What's mine is yours, is that it?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I could use this, too. From the bag he holds up a small GOLD CROSS.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You making an offering to the Reverend Raleigh? Amsterdam slips the cross into his pocket without answeri dig again.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Are you sure we can trust your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOSS TWEED listens to an angry BILL THE BUTCHER as they w a long marble corridor lined with formal portraits of for worthies.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: The building and how many?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: A dozen at least of my Natives.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: The Dead Rabbits are a wooly bunch alright.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I want at them. All of them, and Amsterdam especial. Now.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Not just now. It's between too late and too soon. They've too prominent for comfort, but they're still too small fo your hands. The man who killed Monk Eastman pushing aroun upstarts. It's practically undignified.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: To hell with any of that. Tweed stops under a grand new PORTRAIT of himself.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Very well, and to hell as well with any plans you and I m growth and change and even greater reward. You'll never a beyond the limited perimeter of your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I don't got to advance anywhere further.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Got to, no. But ought to. He hands him a fancy embossed envelope.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (eyes merry) An invitation. To dinner.
