dialogues.text: START CLOSE on: Amsterdam's hand, as he places the gold c hole at a grave site, then covers it over with dirt. Then WE SEE: Amsterdam is kneeling at his father's grave.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: He never had his own cross. Thanks. Now he STANDS and TURNS. Jenny is half-hidden behind an e

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Your touch is light, but as a tracker you work awful heav Now that I met your mother, you should come and meet my f As Jenny starts to WALK towards the grave, we see for the ... that we are in the country, a graveyard in an open fi astonishing PANORAMA of New York and the East River. (MAT is atop a hill, and the East River, busy with ferries and trade, glistens in the near distance. Just beyond it is M low buildings, winding narrow streets, houses surrounded BREEZE off the river rustles Jenny's dress and blows her up to the grave site, looks at the headstone and sees ... ... it is blank. No name, no date. Clean stane.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You should finish the stone.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It'll be finished when everything's finished. That's when hand that killed him is the hand that will bury him in pe He holds up his open hand, covered in dirt.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It was Bill killed him, not you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: With my hand on the knife.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: And his hand on yours!

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: And me feeling the life go out of my father! He looked at at me and he swore me with his eyes. I could feel his spi could feel it rising... flowing through the knife like bl heart.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You talk like he lives in you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I don't want him to live, I want him dead! I kill Bill an them both!

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You think you can be free that easy? You need your way so you''' use anything to clear it. Anyone, too. Me, everybo just a way for you to settle your damned ghosts.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You're part of me now, like the gang is part of me and my I can bring us to glory, then my father... like The Book can enter his house justified. As Amsterdam continues to talk we ...

He FLINGS an expansive arm toward the opposite side of th Bill the Butcher sits with Daniel Killoran and a large gr Amsterdam and the Butcher eye each other with all the old almost ceremonial now, part of the Tradition.

dialogues.text: Their generous support allows me to bring you this splend With their indulgence I'd like to remind you also of the that await you at my new Museum, located on Broadway... There are BOOS from the crowd at such untoward commercial

(continued boos) And to encourage you also in the view that new Albany ord forbidding sportive violence on land shouldn't dampen you wagering. Bets down, entlegen, and you gents.. (indicated fighters) ... fists up! The Fighters come to center ring, circle each other, then A flurry of punches, and Fighter 2 GOES DOWN again. As he the round automatically ends and the between-rounds ritua again.

dialogues.text: Dobbs will take him this round. That'll be something. The never lost before.

dialogues.text: Because there's never been a Dead Rabbit fighting before.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: That'll shame them thorough.

dialogues.text: They got that Conscription Act from Washington keeping th won't leave us alone forever. And the Natives is strong a In the ring, Fighter 1 drives Fighter 2 to the deck again KNOCKS HIM COLD.

dialogues.text: (indicates Fighter 1) You call that strong, John? In the ring, a couple of agitated NATIVE AMERICANS are tr the Rabbit-sponsored winner. RABBITS start to RUSH the ri WAVES them back.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: (trying to make official announcement) The winner... gentlemen, please! ... the winner in the 39 Dead Rabbits champion, High Water Dobbs ... please, gentl The unofficial ring COMBAT continues, knocking Barnum abo champ throws marauding Natives around like empty flower s iumps into the fray, PUSHES some Natives away. They start champ stands them off while Amsterdam WHISPERS to Barnum.

dialogues.text: Just a moment, please, gentlemen! There's a word for us a promises ... (Amsterdam whispers to him briefly) ... something large, something grand, something epic. The are my own words, of course the greatest righting of the ever done in the Five Points. The crowd quiets, their sporting blood still up, curiosit Johnny seems glum, concerned. This is to be a duel not for money, but for honor! A figh

dialogues.text: (interrupting, emphasizing) To the death. If he can stand up to it.

dialogues.speaker: BARNUM
dialogues.text: ... on which money, I hasten to add, may certainly be wag of the two champions are Amsterdam Vallon, here beside me William Poole, known to all as ...

dialogues.text: (leaping up) They know me by any name, you son of a bitch! The crowd ERUPTS: this is a death match between Olympians does not rejoice. He looks at Amsterdam's face, flush wit the right moment has finally come, and he has to turn awa from the ring as Killoran tries unsuccessfully to PULL th and cool him off.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (yelling) I'll have him stretched on a spit! Killoran is beside him now, whispering urgently. Bill the his head vehemently.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (to Killoran) You got no more to say about this now.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Come on, Bill! Let go of your Tammany wet nurse! My chall

dialogues.text: (to Bill) Don't do it, you can't do it! There's the Conscription to elections coming, too. That's your calling now, not these

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'll do my work. But this is a shame, a public shame. It attention. (yelling to Amsterdam) Fine, then! Fine and welcome! Day after elections, we'll on neutral ground to work out time and terms. It will be He walks to the ring, holds his HAND out to Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You know this hand. Last time it was this close, it was o

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I remember it better from another time. He takes the Butcher's hand. The duel is on.

dialogues.text: START CLOSE ON: money being counted out: $300. And a RECE written and given. We think at first this must be a bet b duel between Amsterdam and Bill the Butcher- But we go WIDER to reveal: an office, tables and chairs, lines, in fact. One, very long, filled with young man. An very short, in which a CLERK is handing the receipt to a MAN.

dialogues.text: Your release from service, according to the terms of the Keep it somewhere safe.

dialogues.text: I'll keep it with me. There is only one OTHER PERSON standen behind the Prosper and he steps up quickly and hands $300 to the Clerk as th Young Man heads for the door... ... past the second line, which snakes out into the stree draftees who SHOUT at the Prosperous Young Man as he leav

dialogues.text: Hey, tell your Papa to pass me three hundred dollars too.

dialogues.speaker: DRAFTEE 2
dialogues.text: Tell him if he don't we'll come get you on our way to Get The Prosperous Young Man HURRIES away, but spots Boss Twe Killoran as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: PROSPEROUS YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Oh, Mr. Tweed, I'd take the time to say proper thanks but

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: No thanks owed, son. Conscription's Federal Law, and so's exemption. You might remind your father, though, that you today, minding that the law's strictly and equitably enfo The Prosperous Young Man hurries out, as the Draftees con abuse. Boss Tweed HEADS for them, followed by Killoran.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: You see how much they like this damned law? Enforcing it' us in elections.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: It's not my law, and not my liking, either. But Washingto treated us with sufferance, and we must extend the same r (to Draftees) Boys, we are bound by honor and love of country to fight crisis!

dialogues.speaker: DRAFTEE 4
dialogues.text: We're bound by our wallets and the emptiness in them, tha

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Boys, the union is in distress, our land is wounded deepl suddenly a frail and finite thing. We must ask ourselves

dialogues.speaker: DRAFTEE 5
dialogues.text: Yeah, you could talk a dog off a meat wagen, Tweed. But l fight!

dialogues.speaker: DRAFTEE 6
dialogues.text: That'd be worth twice three hundred dollars to see!

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (as he backs off) Thank you, boys, thank you for your understanding. (to Killoran) Holy Mother. Tweed hustles Killoran outside, where the line of Potenti snakes down the block and into Paradise Square.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Daniel, between the blindness of Washington and the damne Poole Tammany will fall like an autumn leaf. We must take can. Attend to the Butcher. After the elections, of cours think Amsterdam will do our work for us first.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: He could at that. Then he would become a fresh concern

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Not so daunting as this. (turns to the Draftees in the street) Boys, I've just had a word with your compatriots inside, half the sand and a fraction of the spirit they have mani this great struggle... There is a chorus of BOOS and JEEPS from the Draftees out

dialogues.text: Election Day pandemonium. The Dead Rabbits aren't working this day, but Johnny observes the action as Native Americ because of their long dusters--strongarm REPEATERS into t His attention is drawn to a HARRIED TELEGRAPH OPERATOR, w SHOUTED at by Natives as he is inundated by pieces of pap volumes of the voting registry. It's chaos. The poor Oper

dialogues.text: It's chaos here, too. The large main room is filled with OPERATORS receiving election returns. There is SHOUTING a throughout the room. Even Boss Tweed shows signs of worry

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I swear that science will be the death of industry.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORKN
dialogues.text: The telegraph moves the voter tabulation by wire faster t the repeaters in and out.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (losing patience) Your role is to expedite, Daniel, not to explain. (Killoran looks at him blankly) Do something!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: If you'll allow me. They both TURN to see Johnny standing coolly before them.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: There's a scheme we might try.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: You got no place among us, get the hell out of here howev

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: A moment please, Daniel. One moment. (to Johnny) You're a Dead Rabbit, aren't you? Friend to Amsterdam? (Johnny nods) And therefore no particular friend to us. What brings you

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Opportunity. Science and opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: You got opportunities enough among your own.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I did have. But times change faster than people. Some peo I like to stay with the advantage.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Well, then, a Gentleman of foresight! Are you suggesting. you're even saying... that your friend and your gang may lagging behind the great march of history?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Something like that, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Well fine, step up to history then and tell us what you h

dialogues.text: START CLOSE ON: telegraph wire, HUMMING with the election below it--far below--Johnny, Killoran and a couple of TAM looking up at the wire.

dialogues.speaker: BOYO 1
dialogues.text: I ain't goin' up there. I got my election suit on.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: This election'll be over unless we get up there.

dialogues.speaker: KILLORAN
dialogues.text: "We?" This was your notion, you go up there.

dialogues.speaker: BOYO 2
dialogues.text: (looking at polling place) Him. He looks likely, and he ain't workin'. He points over at Sheeny Mike Kurtz, who is observing the polls.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (calls to him) Sheeny Mike, you want to make ... (to Boyo 1) ...how much?

dialogues.speaker: BOYO 1
dialogues.text: A dollar.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (to Sheeny Mike) Five dollars? Just to help us?

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: (a bit wary) What's the pitch, Johnny? Amsterdam wouldn't like it, wor

dialogues.speaker: BOYO 2
dialogues.text: Well, now, if Amsterdam wouldn't like it ...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) He knows about it. Welre working a whole new scheme. But youlre helping, if that's the way you want it. And you ca five. Just start climbing.

dialogues.speaker: SHEENY MIKE
dialogues.text: (beat) Where's the ned? Boyo 2 hands Sheeny Mike five bucks, which he pockets as a large pair of SHEARS. Mike wipes his palms on his pants the pole. For Killoran and the Tammany Boyos, this is like a circus watch Mike's ascent with pleasure. Sheeny Mike is quite pleased with himself as he nears the He turns to look at Johnny and the Tammany group below. A SPECTATORS have stopped to watch as well. Mike gets to the top of the pole, REACHES OUT--STRETCHES telegraph wire with the shears... ... strains... reaches ... MAKES THE CUT. On the ground, Johnny looks relieved. The Boyos offer a p of applause. In the spirit of things, Sheeny Mike TURNS to acknowledge Just briefly. But long enough so he's distracted. He sees FACES fill suddenly with fear, and he TURNS when he HEA.R WHISTLING NOISE. A LIVE TELEGRAPH WIRE is coming at him. He doesn't even h scream. The wire hits him, whipping around him as JOLTS O his body and he FALLS to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PARADISE SQUA.RE DAY
dialogues.text: HANDS pick up the lifeless body of Sheeny Mike and start off... past Amsterdam and Jenny, who stand on one side of and Johnny, who is on the other.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He was working a Tammany job, Tammany will see to him.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: He wasn't Tammany. Not like you.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He made the right choice.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're saying! You killed one of our family!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (slowly) I didn't know he was going to die, Amsterdam. And don't t own and what isn't. You're not my family. And I swear, I Virgin Mother's eyes ... I know what I'm doing, Amsterdam always been blind. (they look at each other) I'll say my farewells. Johnny KNEELS down beside Mike's body, brushes the hair f

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You still smell like drink. He nods to the Rabbits to carry the body on and, as he RI NEWSBOYS DASH into the square, carrying fresh copies of t crying...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSBOYS
dialogues.text: New Tammany victory! Fernando Wood elected to third term! prevails by narrow margin! Boss Tweed vows Armageddon for crime!

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY

As these delicate negotiations continue, the only two out place, Mother Joyce and a Bartender, are listening intent side of the room.

dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.text: OFFICIALS stand on a high wooden platform facing a JEERIN announce a "DRAFT LOTTERY." OFFICIALS are preparing to dr numbers as Boss Tweed gives out with a speech.

dialogues.text: A building burns at the end of the street, spreading a si and flame in the air... ... as a LION CHARGES down the street, growling, scatteri wake. It's a mad, frightening sight, like a fulfillment o prophecy produced by P.T Barnum, whose Museum is burning SCREAMS, YELLS, CURSES and GROANS. CRIES of pain and fear out of the way of the wild animal, then course up the str Broadway burning in the distance. From ABOVE, on the roof of Jacob's Ladder, Amsterdam and madness below.

dialogues.text: (watching lion) That must be the vanguard of Barnum's army.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: This city will burn like Gomorrah.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Then we'll take what we can before it gets too hot.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I think it's past that already.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: It'll never come to that. These people ain't gang-led and purpose. They'd rather die for themselves than the army, that's th would you do?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Fight better and not get so mad. They're only doing what done years ago. Why'd they ever think there was another w

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: They believed what people told them, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What people is that? The Reverend at the mission? Boss Tw Killoran? People like Johnny Sirocco?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: You believed Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Hell.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: And I believed you.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I ain't done nothing different than what I told you, Jen.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I believed what you said abaut being with me, with me alo to me. It's not me alone, it's just you and Bill Poole. Y blood-blind you can't see nothing else, not even this!

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I don't care a fine damn about what they want! It's what won't dare harm the Points, that's all I care about! Let rest of the city into hell! It's another country anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: It's not a country for me, Amsterdam. I don't know about come with me?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Not now.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Now is when I'm going. Will you come?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I don't want all this fighting to go to waste, Jen. I wan it with something. And I got to be waiting for the Butche

dialogues.text: Jenny digs out her treasure from her mother's grave, thro starts to GRAB all the swag she can and hide it on her pe pockets, under her clothes, anywhere. She takes as much a she has to travel fast.

dialogues.text: Beginning a swift series of scenes that are like a laudan The street is JAMMED with people fleeing and people fight forces her way through, trying to escape. A small mob starts to ATTACK a house where a TERRIFIED FA the doorway.

dialogues.text: Cops has everything closed to the north, and the militia'

dialogues.text: As Jenny presses her way through the mob-devoured streets WOMEN and CHILDREN attacking a small group of BLACKS.

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: My Daddy don't have to die for you! Why should he fight a Jenny looks ahead, sees: the river, in the distance. And forward, STUMBLES. Some of the swag FALLS to the street. pick it up as Rioters rush by her.

dialogues.text: MATTE: The surface of the water looks like a mirror made piers are BURNING. The docks are ash. SAILORS battle a MOB for possession of a small rowboat. A boat starts to DRIFT. Jenny spots it, RUNS for it ... but so does ANOTHER GIRL. Younger than Tenny--20 mayb when Amsterdam fell in love with her. They both get to th same time. Each grips it by a gunwale, and they STARE at two jungle beasts over a kill.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I'd kill you for this. The Girl lunges at her with a knite, and Jenny SHOOTS. Th into the flame-reflecting Hudson as if she drowning in a Jenny climbs into the boat and frantically starts to row. her ... working the oars clumsily, furiously ... moving t the water, trying to get away from the city... ... and we go WIDER now. A huge line of IRON--like the si glacier... bisects the frame, then starts to move. Jenny turns, SEES it. It is ... ... the looming hull of an ironclad war ship (MATTE). It into the city, setting off tremendous explosions. Jenny TURNS back for the shore... ... as cannonballs land, devastating rioters.

dialogues.text: MATTE: Police and MILITIA push the rioters back toward th rats. A cannanball EXPLODES in their midst... ... injuring many more cops and militia than rioters. The RUN over the bodies of fallen cops and soldiers. Now the theirs; cops and militia are in retreat. Jenny climbs up on shore and joins the mob as it presses

dialogues.text: Further from the docks. Shells still exploding in the dis moves with the marauding mob, recognizes Doyers Street. And from every lamppos BODY of a black man. Or woman. Or child. Some are still s At the base of a lamppost, a group of RIOTERS have cut op CORPSE of a black man and are pouring oil into it. One of Jenny, grins and holds out the TORCH he's holding. She sh starts to BACK out of the alley. The Rioter touches the torch to the oil in the wound of t body IGNITES in flame. The RIOTERS pull on a rope and the burning, to the top of the lamppost ... ... where its awful shadow joins all the others in the ma refractions on walls all up and down the street. On the s flames dance and the bodies burn, rioters DANCE and SING. From these mad SHADOWS, we...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROOF/JACOB-S LADDER NIGHT
dialogues.text: ... the face of Amsterdam, stepping out of the SHADOWS of are flames in the distance. The whole gang is assembled, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No we ain't going to fight, but we can take something for this.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: I want to know who hung them bodies in the Bloody Angle. who done it.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Five thousand people in the street done it! Boss Tweed do Lincoln done it! There's nothing you can do about any one with us. You'll have a little of your own back.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: These riots are a gift. They... ... he PAUSES just for a moment as he sees a hand on the outside ladder leading to the roof: it's Jenny, returning

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: ... they've made everything clear, as you might say. (to Jenny) Are you with us, then?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Until I can get out. I'll go with you... (straight at Amsterdam) ...meantime.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Good. We're going for the Armory at Canal Street.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: The Armory! We'll have to beat the militia to get there.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: There's a way through the lines. Jen, did you see the cop

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: I can show you from here where they are. I doubt they'll in force before midday tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: We'll get there first. We'll take everything we can carry rest so no one else has the use of it, the militia, the N Then we'll turn to real business. We'll go down to the Ba

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY SPOILS
dialogues.text: Why, we going to take a sail to Europe?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No. But we could, after this. We're going... (slowly, savoring this) ...we're going to take the banks. The government banks. (awed silence from all) Are we not?

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (beat; steps forward) Seems we are. One by one, then in small groups, the entire gang FOLLOWS uncertain, reluctant, even frightened at the audacity of they stand with Amsterdam.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN ROOM/TAMMANY HALL NIGHT
dialogues.text: The crowded main room of Boss Tweed's domain, jammed with POLITICOS and OFFICIALS, as well as a harried group of TE who receive news of the riots from all over Manhattan. Th of the city against one wall: the place has been converte political princedom to an operational headquarters. Johnn Bill The Butcher are there. Other guests include the GOVE Fernando Wood, and a badly shaken Horace Greeley.

dialogues.speaker: GREELEY
dialogues.text: They attacked me! I had every sympathy for them at first.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Too much sympathy, Horace. Writing these riots were a ris "unjust laws and unsuitable law-givers." The shame!

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: I suspended the draft at noon but the mobs only grew more a criminal rising of the lowest class, of the Gangsters a have been allowed by Tammany to run lawless!

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: It was Tammany and the rabble that elected you, Governor. and the gangs who'll stop it. Isn't that so, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (nods at Johnny) I won't say nothin' in front of him. Who knows what busin

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: He's here on our business and my invitation. He's already help. What's the opposition strength, John? To answer, Johnny yanks back a CURTAIN drawn across a hig view, looking downtown, is one of almost continual ILLUMI place the eye falls, CANDLES burn in sympathy for the rio

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Each candle is against you, gents.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: "Against you," sir? Don't you mean "us".

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (diplomatic) Some of us come from those people, Mayor. I'll not deny t part of me.

dialogues.speaker: MAYOR
dialogues.text: Which part? Perhaps your heart.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I'm sorry you find it necessary to question th friend here, and by extension, my own judgement. So as pr where will the mob go? What will the gangs do? (Johnny is uneasy about answering) Go on, tell them what you told me.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: There's no telling about the mob. Or the small gangs. But ... if I was Amsterdam...

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (interrupting) As indeed you nearly was. Were.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: ... if I was ... I'd figure to take the Rabbits to the Ar

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Would you agree with that, Bill? Wouldn't you do the same fighting against the militia instead of beside them?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Beside them? What are you talking... ?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: (interrupting) You will have to fight beside them to take the Armory. It unfriendly hands.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I can't stand with the militia against the people. I coul Points no more if I did.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: We're all of us swept up in a great tide of events, Bill. to swim? From Bill's face, struggling to make sense of this, knowi but not wanting to believe it, we ...

dialogues.speaker: INT. MAIN ROOM/TAMMANY HALL NIGHT
dialogues.text: ... Johnny's face, as Tweed talks to him. It is later, an left. The activity is still frantic all around, but Tweed unhurried tones.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: I'm sure that Bill will do his usual splendid job. But af well, I'm afraid he's grown away from us. (Johnny looks puzzled) He shows distressing signs of... shall we say, free-think flourishes in chaos, and these riots could encourage Bill himself. He no longer inspires in me the same trust... we might. If you can prove yourself further.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You already said in front of everyone you trusted me.

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: In vital things. Would I be talking to you now otherwise? but small things. Are you equal to greater responsibility

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Such as what?

dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Ridding me of Bill the Butcher. (Johnny is startled) He may question your loyalty to me, but Bill would never the sand to go against him. He'd never expect it. Do you From Johnny's face, struggling to make the right answer,

dialogues.text: ... Ansterdam's face, as he looks up from preparing a bra the next day's scheme.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Let him in. Johnny enters the common room of Jaccb's Ladder, where th have gathered to ready themselves. As they work over thei prepare battle dress, Johnny walks through their midst. T acknowledge him... except for Jenny.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: Did you miss us, John?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Not a bit.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (rising to meet him) Are you here to spy?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I don't have to spy. Amsterdam leads Johnny off to a shadowy corner of the roo talk privately.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (as they walk) I know what you're doing. I told Tweed what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You don't know what I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You're going after the Armory.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Am I now? Why do you think that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: 'Cause that's what I would do, and you and I think alike.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: No more. And it don't seem worth a visit to tell me somet think I'm doing.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: There's something else alright. Tweed's arranged to kill

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (disbelieving) Who could Tweed get to do that?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: One of his own.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: There's no one around him...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Listen, it don't matter who, it's going to be done, that' ain't going to wait around for you and Bill to settle yourselves. I'm telling you so chance.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Chance of what?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: A chance... a chance to do what you want. Bury the Butche blood you got to. But you better make speed. The Natives Armory too.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: And what's any of it mean to you?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: It means whatever's left of friendship, I don't know. The of me here. I don't want to see you lose everything in your life at once.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'm going to lose nothing. (beat) If you believe me, you can stay.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I got to go. He turns so Amsterdam can't see his face and LEAVES-

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: So Tammany's going to kill the Butcher. That puts you and same side. Does that make the path clear enough to suit y From Amsterdam's face, trying to work out all the new ang

And Bill the Butcher gazes at him with astonishment. We a time, in the Natives' lair, a house hung with American fl and vintages, some of them torn by battle, others by year use. Some of them go back to the early days of the republ an inch of wood or wall space to be seen for all the star

dialogues.text: Murder Me? No one's going to murder me.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Then you better learn to fight locking over your shoulder that's the only way you'll ever see it coming.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I don't believe it, and I don't believe it's you telling reason to care about any danger to me.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: One reason. You're my kill, Butcher. No one else is going Tweed, not Tammany, not those pigs in the street. No one- Bill--will ever take the pleasure of your death away from anything to keep you for my own, even if I have to protec

dialogues.text: You protect me? Get out of here and go to hell.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Fine, so long as I pass you on my way.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe I'd believe you more if I knew who was talking to y

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Someone I credit.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: That means nothing to me. None of this means nothing to m Tammany. Without me and my Natives they're nothing but a horses at a trough.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: You join with me and we fight against Tammany, fight them the Points. Then you and me can settle. But if you don't then there won't be no settlement because you'll be murde and the whole Points will be mine.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I relish the thought... just the thought... of cutting yo you wide. So if just thinking about it gives me such plea I'm going to enjoy doing it.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Why don't I make it easy for you, then. He TURNS his back on the Butcher and starts to walk out, entire gang of Natives.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Same as you're making it easy for Tweed. He keeps walking... through the Natives ... dozens of anc glowering at him.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Amsterdam! (Amsterdam looks around) Don't be like your father. Don't make it too easy. Amsterdam struggles to keep his temper. But he turns and through the enemy camp as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....Amsterdam walking. But this time, he is WALKING among the Dead Rabbits are assembled, weapons ready. Jenny is b Jimmy Spoils. Then a few others. As the group passes, others STAND and walk with them... ... until the whole gang is rallied... ... and bound for the passageway in the corner of the roo under the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Amsterdam and the gang heads through the catacomb-like the graves, into a tunnel. Torchlight GUTTERS all around. like repeated rifle shots.

dialogues.text: The whole gang MARCHES down a tunnel under the Old Brewer Amsterdam and Jenny, they all wear their tamlas. Many hav insignia on their faces. All of them have weapons. A lot Frightened FACES--people seeking shelter and safety from in the darkness, then vanish like ghosts. As the Rabbits walk, they summon memories of the first fi march through the tunnels when Amsterdam marched beside h Amsterdam's face gives little away. But perhaps he is rem too.

dialogues.text: The last tunnel.. Shreds of light from a door in the dist walks up to the door and--just as Monk Eastman did years down. Dim dawn LIGHT FLOODS the tunnel as the Dead Rabbit

dialogues.text: The first thing we see is an ELEPHANT, who trumpets fearf sudden sound of the sattere door. The gang stops, wary of refugee from Barnum's Museum, but the animal is more frig It hurries on down the street... ... revealing behind it a group of several dozen RIOTERS American flag and a long wooden plank bearing the legend stare at the Rabbits with something near reverence.

dialogues.text: Where's the Native Americans?

dialogues.speaker: RIOTER
dialogues.text: Ain't seen them. Ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: And the militia?

dialogues.speaker: RIOTER
dialogues.text: There's a detachment coming on from two streets over. The north of here. What are you after? Amsterdam POINTS to a formidable building a block away: t looks like a fortress.

dialogues.speaker: RIOTER
dialogues.text: The Devil himself couldn't take that place.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: That's why he sent us.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET NEAR ARMORY/ DAY
dialogues.text: The DETACHMENT of militia proceeds warily towards the Arm young, uncertain-looking outfit; their COMMANDER looks li farm kid. He tenses and his eyes widen as he sees Jenny w him, carrying a BOY in her arms.

dialogues.speaker: JENNY
dialogues.text: (crying) Help me. Oh please help me. He's shot, we need a doctor,

dialogues.speaker: DETACHMENT COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Miss, we ain't a medical outfit. The main unit's ten minu they'll have... He doesn't get the chance to finish. Jenny DROPS the Boy shoots the Detachment Commander once, cleanly... ... as the Boy roles into a prone position and FIRES two stunned Detachment... ... while the Dead Rabbits SWARM from every doorway along FIRING GUNS and brandishing weapons. It's over in seconds. The Detachment has hardly gotten of one of them lies dead or wounded in the street... ... as the Rabbits CROUCH over their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ARMORY DAY
dialogues.text: A rifle emplacement manned by a dozen GUARDS- They stand front of the Armory. Each window is barred and fortified, door is massive. But the tension in the Guards' faces eas they see ... ... the Detachment of militia heading towards them down t of the Detachment are wearing bloody uniform jackets; sev carried. The Detachment, unrecognized by the Guards, is m of Dead Rabbits.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Help us, we got wounded!

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 1
dialogues.text: We can't leave the post.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Open the damn doors then! We're bad hurt!

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 1
dialogues.text: Where's the others?

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Just behind us! But I got our major here wounded so bad h out! Guard 1 SIGNALS for the doors to be opened to the Armory draws close to the emplacement.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD 1
dialogues.text: God, it's good to see you!

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: Likewise. Ainsterdam SHOOTS him where he stands as the Rabbits OVER emplacement.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (shouting) Move fast! We got to get out with everything we can befor gets here! As the Armory Guards return fire, the Boy Jenny carried i scene RUNS for the telegraph pole and starts to CLIMB. A wood fly inches from his face... ... as the Rabbits storm into the Armory, FIRING wildly. The Boy reaches the top of the telegraph pole and CUTS th shinnies back down the pole as the wire SWINGS ineffectua and we ...

The Book says in Revelations, "I saw a new earth." If the hand of God's not on you to fulfill then the hand of Tweed will be. Go on and God bless. dialogues.speaker: BOSS TWEED
dialogues.text: Oh, I think he can. Whether it's one man against another the city, the mathematics remain the same. You never enjo enlightenment of poverty, did you, Governor? If you had, can always hire half the poor to kill the other half.

As SHOT WIDENS, the carnage is revealed. Bodies their uniform dusters, and Rabbits, in their tamlas, lie the street.

He's closer t Bill starts to mount their BARRICADE. There is MOVEMENT a around him as Natives and militia fall into rough formati to obscure Bill from Johnny's view. Shield him. He has to make his move. NOW. He DRAWS a revolver as mili pass in front of him... he AIMS ... he's anxious, confuse shakes ... he fires... too soon! ... ... and HITS a Native, who falls dead. Right near Bill. The Butcher turns in the direction of the shot, SEES John lock. Johnny FIRES again ... WINGS Bill ... ... and Bill SHOOTS him. Johnny FALLS with the first shot him now, looking down at him.

dialogues.text: Was it Tweed or your friend put you to this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Tweed. Bill SHOOTS him again, point blank. Johnny screams.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You'd lie to save your friend.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (in terrible pain) No. There's no friends for me.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: Me the same. Pity us both. He EMPTIES his revolver into Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: (to his men) Hold your fire! (toward the Armory) In there! Hey in there! I want to talk to Amsterdam! The Militia Commander is aghast at this proposition and s gun in hand. But a Native STOPS him. Amsterdam's face APPEARS in a front window of the Armory.

dialogues.text: Go on, then, talk.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: You and me.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: (beat) Come ahead then. And bring my friend's body. Bill the Butcher SLINGS Johnny's body over his shoulder a were an empty sack of flour... ... and starts walking thraugh the lines toward the Armor watches in disbelief, the Natives in confusion. The Dead Butcher in their sights. But no one fires. No one moves. And Bill the Butcher enters the front doors of the Armory

And enough rifles and munitions to sink Manha Bill the Butcher stands dead center in the middle of the Amsterdam walks toward him. The Butcher DROPS Johnny's bo his feet.

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: I'm not forgetting where I put it.

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: If you do, I'll remind you. (he turns, leaves)

dialogues.speaker: AMSTERDAM
dialogues.text: What's your call, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILL THE BUTCHER
dialogues.text: I'm considering where's my better chance. He walks to the doors. The Rabbits guarding it don't make it himself and strides out into the street.

The Butcher and the Militia Commander argue, but we still they're saying. There is still no sound... ... until, SUDDENLY, we see the Militia Commander's face. with surprise as we HEAR the thunderclap of a SHOT. Bill the Butcher has just gutshot the Militia Commander. As if the shot were a signal, the Natives TURN on the mil hellish, close-quarter combat. Guns fired inches from ene been allies. Knives, swords, bludgeons, kids with dead-ra women with hob-nailed wooden planks, attacking better-arm stunned soldiers. And that unleashes a from the Armory... ... toward the militia. Other Natives never m doors. And a few are shot... ... when the doors close before they can get through.

As Jenny runs, her swag drops and FALLS from under her cl to pick it up but Amsterdam PULLS her on.... ... and just away from the titanic EXPLOSION of the Armor throws some of the militia from their perches on the roof fountain of FLAME and RUBBLE high into the sky. It is VOL brilliance and intensity. The sky turns BLACK with powder with flame. In the small streets BEHIND THE ARMORY, many gang members debris or burned by FIREBALLS breaking off from the centr The Armory is gone. Much of the surrounding area is gone On the ground, everything is smoke, flame, dirt, death, c everywhere. Gang members and kids running all over, despe like the last day of mankind on earth.
